elements.text: [Part One]

Begin letter now. (beep) My Lady Vuyoki, why so coy? We find ourselves, you and I, caught in a net of eternal twilight, thrown together on this gods-forsaken rock. It clutches at us and holds us tight. Time sluices around it, past and possible dash against it, but it sticks as an obdurate hope-lost trap of nothingness. Come here to us, my Lady.
[OC]: Commander!

I fear for your safety alone on the reef. Darkness lurks in the gullies and cracks of our prison. As monsters go, the Ruhk is foul-hearted and cunning, a liar and a thief. Avoid it, my Lady, at all cost. My crew and I are rough voyagers, but our ship is sound. We seek to cut her free from the coral that binds us all here, so let our shelter be yours also.
Banging on door.
[OC]: Commander Gammades?
Pause letter. (beep) Enter.
Door opens.
Captain Lucor? What's the matter? I have a letter to compose.
Sir, it's Eumachus. He's out on the reef.
Oh, the idiot. It's not safe out there.
He's taken Coris with him, and a line drum. He's launched himself up off the ridge.
What's the ninny playing at? I warned him.
He's got the beacon with him, sir.
The beacon?
He's trying to reach the surface. Says maybe it'll work out there.
Deep gods, the fool'll kill us all.
Reel the line out another three spans, Coris.
[OC]: Aye, sir.
Steady. Too much, you'll be breaking the surface.
[OC]: Eumachus? This is Gammades. What the chasm are you playing at? Get back to the ship now.
Don't panic, Gammas, old chap. You see, I told you my opposable gravity suit would work. Look. I'm a kite on a string.
GAMMADESJOC]: You'll get yourself killed, and lose the beacon in the process.
Woo-hoo! I can see the whole reef from up here. Tell you what, though. It's growing faster than we thought. Soon it'll fill the whole bubble.
[OC]: That beacon's our only hope. Gods know, it cost us dear enough.
Yes, it doesn't work, though, does it? Not down there. So let's try it up nearer the surface.
[OC]: The oxygen in that suit's gone to your head, boy.
You should see the sky up close.
[OC]: It's like diving into the maelstrom. Oi, Coris, wake up. Let's have one more span.
[OC]: Commander?
No, reel him in now.
[OC]: Aye, Commander.
[OC]: Oh, come on, Gammas, don't be such a stump in the mud. Give it a try. Isn't that what heroes do?
Wait. Wait, Coris.
[OC]: Have a bit of faith. Not like we can sacrifice for a fair wind, is it? Not since the Ruhk stole all the goats...
Oh, go on then, try the beacon. Just don't touch the surface, eh?
[OC]: The bubble won't burst. I'm running the beacon now.
Well, is it working? Eumachus?
[OC]: No, not a skin sock. This star thing's as cold as cheese. You were taken for a ride when you bought that, old chap.
Monster ahoy!
Commander, over there. There's a shadow crawling up the ridge.
I see it.
It's the Ruhk.
Making rook-like cawing sounds.
That evil broken-winged night bird. It'll kill them. Eumachus, it's the Ruhk.
[OC]: Oh, gods!
We're bringing you in.
Coris, reel Eumachus in. Get him in, now.
[OC]: Fast as I can, sir.
[OC]: Hurry it up, Coris. That monster's closing in.
Luc, haul the harpoon.
Wrong angle. We'd have to swing the whole ship round.
We can't just stand here. Coris, hurry up.
The Ruhk's getting closer.
Open the doors. I'm going up there.
Not enough time, sir.
[OC]: Coris, look out!
Coris!
Coris’s scream fades rapidly.
He fell. Coris fell. It knocked him right down the ridge.
Deep gods. Eumachus, hold on. We'll get you down.
[OC]: Too late, Commander. It's got hold of the line.
The Ruhk's hauling him in.
It's after the beacon.
[OC]: Not if I can help it. Get away from the line, you monster.
Eumachus, what are you doing?
[OC]: Cutting the line, Commander.
Don't be a fool.
[OC]: Fish me down later, Gammas. It's not having the beacon, I'd rather die.
Eumachus, no! Eumachus!
He's cut himself free.
[OC]: (laughs) Hello down there!
Thank the gods he still lives. Eummachus, you fool, keep clear of the surface. Don't touch the Vortex. Euma...
Fizz, cries out.
Gad, I can't see. Lucor. Where's Eumachus?
He's still there, knocking against the surface of the Vortex.
Alive?
Hard to tell.
[OC]: (laughs) Hello down there!
Well, that answers that. Where's the Ruhk?
Lost it. It moved away.
Good. What's the idiot doing now? Eumachus, you're drifting. Eumachus!
Not sure he's still with us, sir.
What do you mean, man? He's there, I can see him.
[OC]: Hello down there! (laughs)
And hear him.
[OC]: (fading) Hello down there!
It’s his last moment, sir, repeating itself. He's dead and dying, over and over again.

Poor boy. A curse on these rocks and this damned reef. Curse the Ruhk. And curse the damned Doctor who brought us here and abandoned us all to our fate! (echoes) To our fate! To our fate! To our fate! To our fate! To our fate! To our fate! To our fate...!
Doctor?
There was a left here. What's he done with the left?
Doctor?
Second right from the control room, second left, third right, and then first left again.
The quick route to the spare equipment store, yes.
Only there isn't another first left, just a dead wall.
Then we've come the wrong way.
Nyssa, do you think I don't know my own Tardis?
How long is it since we were here? Five Earth months? That's a long time.
And it's not right. The ship feels used, and the engines sound wrong.
It probably just needs a little fine-tuning, that's all.
And there used to be a rattle from the control mounting whenever we took off. It's been there for years.
Yes, I remember that.
Well, now it's gone. And there are other rattles, new rattles, creaks.
Oh, even worse.
Exactly. The whole ship's heaving like a storm-tossed galleon. Can't you hear it?
I think you're exaggerating. Come on, let's get you a cup of tea.
That boy.
Doctor...
Thomas Brewster, the boy who stole my Tardis.
He borrowed it.

He marooned us. Scattered off on his own, going goodness knows where, doing goodness knows what. Though I doubt goodness had much to do with it. And it takes a poor lost ghost to bring him back to heel, his tail between his legs.
He's very young.
Oh well, that makes all the difference.
Tea, Doctor.
If there's any tea left. Hang on. Hang on, this door.
This one? What about it?
It doesn't belong.
Yes, Doctor.
There shouldn't be a door here, not just here.
Then let's see what's inside.
Don't touch! We don't know where it goes. It could lead inside the Power House, or directly into the Vortex.
Hardly likely, is it?
Better safe than sorry.
Oh, at this rate we'll be here all day. Stand back.
Nyssa!
The control room. But that's impossible.
Hello. Didn't expect you two strollers back so quick.
We can't be back here. Not from there.
Not unless someone's been messing about with the inner dimensions.
I ain't done nothing. Don't look at me.
Funny, that. I don't see anyone else to look at. Maybe he has something more to tell us, eh Nyssa?
Oi, now, don't you start.
Such as where he's been all the time he stranded us in a primitive polluted den of thieving and vice...
That's my home you're talking about.
Doctor, Thomas may have left us for five months...
Abandoned.
Just Brewster, Miss.
But in the Tardis's own relative time-stream, he might only have been away for five minutes.
Yeah, that's right. Wink of the old peepers.
Not from the accumulation of evidence on offer. So where have you been, and what have you done to my...? Is that my shirt you're wearing?
I wondered when you'd notice.
It is. You're wearing my shirt.
I had to wear something. Sides, I ain't no lully triper. There was a whole cupboard full. All different sizes. Can't all be yours though, can they?
I'm sure you could spare one.
That's not the point. Not content with hijacking my ship, he helps himself to... Nyssa, where are you going?
I'm going to get you that cup of tea. Talk to Brewster, Doctor, not me.
Nyssa, be careful - the dimensions out there aren't...
Door closes.
Stable.
So...

All right. All right, so I may have been hasty. Launching out into Time and Space on your own can be a unnerving experience, downright terrifying actually. That doesn't change, however long you've travelled.
I'm sorry, Doctor. It is an amazing ship though, the Tardis. Your Tardis.
Yes. I think so too. Right. First we're running a full systems fault check to see what the damage is. Now then... (beeps) That's odd. The fault location system's on the blink.
Really?
That shouldn't happen. Let's take a look down here. What? Where's it gone? It's vanished. The fault locator unit. Someone's taken it out. Brewster?
Door opens.
Me? Now, hang on a mo.
Doctor, the food machine...
Not now, Nyssa.
But it's gone.
Gone?
Grinding of metal.
Blimey, what was that?
I wouldn't know, Brewster. You tell me.
4 Can you find me, look behind me, in the dark before the dawn. Do not leave me, please retrieve me, I am waiting to be...
Tap on ceramics.
Born. Who's there?
[OC]: My Lady Vuyoki?
Go away. I'm waiting to be spirited to my new life.
[OC]: My Lady, I come to your ship bearing a message from Commander Gammades.
Oh, not again. You may look in upon me.
Ceramic lid scrapes.
Careful with the lid, idiot. This bridal urn has served my family for generations.
Forgive me, my Lady.
You find it amusing that I live inside a jar?
No, my Lady.
What about your tiny brain rattling round your empty skull? That's much funnier. So, what have you brought? A salutation, or gifts?
The Commander's message. Here.
All right, all right, stand away.
My Lady.
Further. Further! A lady must breathe. No, don't go, idiot. Wait for my reply.
[OC]: My Lady Vuyoki, why so coy?
Coy?
[OC]: We find ourselves, you and I, caught in a net of eternal twilight, thrown together on this gods-forsaken rock...
Oh, really.
[OC]: It clutches at us and holds us tight...
There's nothing worse than an amateur poet.
Fast forward.
[OC]: Our ship is sound. We seek to cut her free from the coral that binds us all here, so let our shelter be yours also.
Shelter? Oh, how touching. You. Yes, you.
Huh?
How does this grubby object work? How do I send back my answer? Well? Come on, I can't do everything myself.
Tardis engines stuttering.
I can't make out these readings. They don't correlate.
Nope, none of them do. Right, that should hold.
String? You're trusting yourself to a ball of string?
Bailer twine. Unwound, it should get me as far as the auxiliary junctions. If I tug the line twice, start hauling me back.
Are you sure that's necessary? The corridors were stable just now.
But they weren't before that.
That's true.
The fact is, we don't know how much damage Brewster's done, do we?
I keep telling you, I ain't done nothing.
Right Nyssa, open the inner door, would you?
Door opens.
It looks safe enough.
Let's hope so. Remember, two tugs on the line.
Please be careful.
And don't let him touch anything. I'll be back as quick as I can.
Brewster?
Don't you start.
Look, I thought we were friends. The food machine and the fault locator, is that all that's missing?
How should I know?
Because I think there's a lot else that isn't here any more. The whole dimensional structure of the Tardis has destabilised.
Don't ask me. I belong in the gutter with the rest of the slush.
That's silly. I wish you'd tell us where you went.
None of your business.
I'm trying to help. I Know the Doctor's angry, but if you tell him the truth he'll understand.
What do you care? Swanning about, giving yourself airs like a princess. I know a proper lady, see, and she owes me a cartload of favours.
Is that someone you've met? Brewster, where have you been?
Hell and back.
[OC]: Nyssa, help me!
Doctor?
Look at the passageway. It's all sliding through itself.
The dimensions are folding in. We've got to get him out of there.
[OC]: Commander Gammades, I thank you for your most generous offer - which I fear I must decline.
But why must you?
[OC]: As you say, you are rough voyagers.
Oh...
[OC]: And a lady of Marabou must maintain her quality. You see, dear Gammades, you would never be more than a servant to me. And of course, I would never desire to demean your standing.
What standing? We're all of us shipwrecked on this accursed rock.
[OC]: So, I must wait alone for Old Birth to take me, and lament how you can never be part of my newborn life. (laughs) There. Finished. How do I switch this thing off?
What spirit she has. No, my Lady. Such determined grace only fans the flames of my ardour, and one day soon, we shall be as one.
[OC]: Nyssa, help me!
Brewster, help me pull him back.
I am. Can't see nothing down there. It's black as pitch.
Doctor, hold on!
[OC]: Nyssa!
His hand. Oh, it's freezing cold!
[OC]: Help me!
I couldn't hold him. He's gone, Brewster. The Doctor's gone.
Not if I can help it he ain't.
No, Brewster, don't.
Af! It's freezing. Can hardly feel my fin. Oh, come on, Doctor, grab my hand.
Thomas, come away. You'll die.
I can't let him go, not like this. It ain't right. Ah! I've got him. I've got him!
Pull. Keep pulling. Doctor, you're safe.
Just about. Brewster? Was that you who pulled me clear?
Both of us, Nyssa and me.
Thank you. I, I'm sorry, I ... I couldn't - reach the junctions. I seem to be covered in ice.
Here, put your coat on. Brewster, rub that arm or you'll get frostbite.
Yes, Miss.
And I think we'd better shut this.
Door closes.
Oh! The relative structure of the Tardis is in flux. It's all breaking down. We can't leave the control room.
There's still the doors to the outside.
Not while we're in flight. But we could try the conceptual geometer. It maps out the Tardis's interior. If we could access that...
My first thought too. (beep) But wouldn't you know it, the geometer's not registering either. Where is it, Brewster? Still in the ship, or did you sell it off for cheap gin and a pie?
Doctor, stop hectoring him. It isn't helping.
Perhaps not, but it makes me feel better. Now, if I can just find out where the Tardis has been,
may be our only chance. Well, there's a miracle. The memory bank's still intact.
What's he doing?
Getting worried now, are you?
The Doctor's checking the Tardis's recent flights.
And destinations.
That's private. I don't go checking up on you.
Right then, back journey number one.
Don't go there, Doctor.
Go where? These coordinates don't even add up.
Just don't, that's all.
There's no spatial or temporal locations.
Exactly. They don't exist. But if the Tardis has been before, she'll remember.
She's barely holding together.
Doctor, I'm begging you, please.
Let's go.
The Tardis dematerialises.
Alarm sounding.
Lucor, what's that racket?
Not sure, Commander. It suddenly started up. I'm trying to pinpoint its source.
It's the beacon. It must be. Where's Eumachus?
His orbit's due round any moment. Horizon at dawn point.
Hmm?
And... up he rises. You could run a clock off him.
[OC]: Hello down there!
If only we could reach him.
I told you, it's the beacon. It's working at last. And you thought it was a bad trade. Twenty goldoons for the first man to sight rescue.
Cheers.
There's a proper swell getting up on the surface.
Future and past in ferment. Deep gods, I need a gale of fresh Time blowing in my face.
Looks like it's building up into a real Time storm. Heavy weather ahead, lads. Everyone, below decks, ready to batten the force-shields.
Maybe it'll blow the Ruhk away.
Something's coming through.
The Tardis materialises.
I know that's sound. It's him. He's coming back. It's the Doctor.
Systems under stress. Imminent structural collapse. What's that noise?
A distress signal. I don't believe it, it's another Tardis.
Another Tardis?
Brewster, perhaps you could shed some light.
I don't know what you mean.
Doctor, the inner wall's rupturing. It won't hold.
I know that signal. It's not another Tardis, it's this one. That's the alarm on the missing conceptual geometer. It's calling to us.
It can't be. Unless it's wreckers, drawing us in.
We could home in on that signal manually, if we last that long.
Too late. We're on collision course.
The walls!
Hang on tight.
The Tardis materialises.
Out, both of you.
The interior's collapsing.
Get clear!
Sucking noise, silence.
What happened?
It's gone.
Gone? What do you mean, gone?
The whole internal structure of the Tardis just imploded.
But there must be some way to recover it.
You saw for yourself. The interior dimensions compacted. They crushed down to a single knot, a
nothing. My Tardis is dead.
It can't be, I mean, surely we can do something?
We can't. It's over.
What?
Brewster. I think the Doctor would like to be on his own for a few moments. Over here.
Is he all right?
He's in shock. The Tardis was his home for a long, long time. He's lost an old friend.
I can see that. Look, we can't stay here.
It doesn't look terribly welcoming, does it? It’s so airless and barren, like the surface of an asteroid. You've been here before, haven't you? What happened? Why are you so scared?
I'm not. Oh, you wouldn't understand.
Well, if you won't talk to me, at least speak to the Doctor.
An excellent suggestion, Nyssa. I'd be most interested in what Master Brewster has to say. If he has a mind to speak, that is.
I don't know.
Maybe it's better if I'm not here.
Don't wander too far.
I won't.
Now then, Brewster, what about this place?
Dunno. You can see, can't ya? It's a rock - no sun, no stars. The sort of place the Beak send you when you get transported.

It might as well be. Do you know what this rock is, Brewster? It's a reef of space corals, stuck in a bubble of existence where nothing can exist. But how it got here, I couldn't say. And those lights up there are the energetic patterns of the Time Vortex outside playing across the surface of the bubble. Like being underwater, isn't it?
Never was much cop at swimming.
But it's not deserted, is it? You see? Shards of pottery, scattered all over. Not old either, from the patterns, I'd say. Umian, possibly Marabou. One of the late dynasties.
I told you, I don't know nothing.
[OC]: (laughs) Hello down there!
What's that?
Up there, by the surface. A man in a spacesuit. He's waving. Some friend of yours, perhaps. Hello up there.
Don't do that.
Why not? Scared of attracting trouble?
Doctor, is that you?
Too late.
Who are these people? Someone I should know?
Hook them. Well, well. Who's your friend, Doctor? Another liar?
Scarce it. Run!
Oh no you don't, lad. Not that way.

Well, Doctor. We thought you'd abandoned us. But no one ever escapes this place, eh? Not even you. What shall we do with him, eh, lads? Stake him out on the rocks and leave him for the night- winged Ruhk to feed on?
The Ruhk?
Hello? Is anyone there? My name is Nyssa. I mean you no harm.
Nyssa. I smell your fear.
Who... who are you?
I was the Ruhk.
You were the Ruhk? So who are you now?
I am the hunter, and there is no escape.

GAMMADES: Deep gods, the fool'll kill us all.

CORIS: [OC]: Aye, sir.
EUMACHUS: Steady. Too much, you'll be breaking the surface.

EUMACHUS: Woo-hoo! I can see the whole reef from up here. Tell you what, though. It's growing faster than we thought. Soon it'll fill the whole bubble.

EUMACHUS: [OC]: It's like diving into the maelstrom. Oi, Coris, wake up. Let's have one more span.

GAMMADES: No, reel him in now.
CORIS: [OC]: Aye, Commander.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Oh, come on, Gammas, don't be such a stump in the mud. Give it a try. Isn't that what heroes do?
GAMMADES: Wait. Wait, Coris.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Have a bit of faith. Not like we can sacrifice for a fair wind, is it? Not since the Ruhk stole all the goats...
GAMMADES: Oh, go on then, try the beacon. Just don't touch the surface, eh?
EUMACHUS: [OC]: The bubble won't burst. I'm running the beacon now.
GAMMADES: Well, is it working? Eumachus?
EUMACHUS: [OC]: No, not a skin sock. This star thing's as cold as cheese. You were taken for a ride when you bought that, old chap.
PLESTER: Monster ahoy!
LUCOR: Commander, over there. There's a shadow crawling up the ridge.
GAMMADES: I see it.
LUCOR: It's the Ruhk.
GAMMADES: That evil broken-winged night bird. It'll kill them. Eumachus, it's the Ruhk.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Oh, gods!
GAMMADES: We're bringing you in.
LUCOR: Coris, reel Eumachus in. Get him in, now.
CORIS: [OC]: Fast as I can, sir.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Hurry it up, Coris. That monster's closing in.
GAMMADES: Luc, haul the harpoon.
LUCOR: Wrong angle. We'd have to swing the whole ship round.
GAMMADES: We can't just stand here. Coris, hurry up.
LUCOR: The Ruhk's getting closer.
GAMMADES: Open the doors. I'm going up there.
LUCOR: Not enough time, sir.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Coris, look out!
GAMMADES: Coris!
LUCOR: He fell. Coris fell. It knocked him right down the ridge.
GAMMADES: Deep gods. Eumachus, hold on. We'll get you down.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Too late, Commander. It's got hold of the line.
LUCOR: The Ruhk's hauling him in.
GAMMADES: It's after the beacon.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Not if I can help it. Get away from the line, you monster.
GAMMADES: Eumachus, what are you doing?
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Cutting the line, Commander.
GAMMADES: Don't be a fool.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Fish me down later, Gammas. It's not having the beacon, I'd rather die.
GAMMADES: Eumachus, no! Eumachus!
LUCOR: He's cut himself free.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: (laughs) Hello down there!
GAMMADES: Thank the gods he still lives. Eummachus, you fool, keep clear of the surface. Don't touch the Vortex. Euma...
GAMMADES: Gad, I can't see. Lucor. Where's Eumachus?
LUCOR: He's still there, knocking against the surface of the Vortex.
GAMMADES: Alive?
LUCOR: Hard to tell.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: (laughs) Hello down there!
GAMMADES: Well, that answers that. Where's the Ruhk?
LUCOR: Lost it. It moved away.
GAMMADES: Good. What's the idiot doing now? Eumachus, you're drifting. Eumachus!
LUCOR: Not sure he's still with us, sir.
GAMMADES: What do you mean, man? He's there, I can see him.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Hello down there! (laughs)
GAMMADES: And hear him.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: (fading) Hello down there!
LUCOR: It’s his last moment, sir, repeating itself. He's dead and dying, over and over again.
GAMMADES: Poor boy. A curse on these rocks and this damned reef. Curse the Ruhk. And curse the damned Doctor who brought us here and abandoned us all to our fate! (echoes) To our fate! To our fate! To our fate! To our fate! To our fate! To our fate! To our fate...!
NYSSA: Doctor?
DOCTOR: There was a left here. What's he done with the left?
NYSSA: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Second right from the control room, second left, third right, and then first left again.
NYSSA: The quick route to the spare equipment store, yes.
DOCTOR: Only there isn't another first left, just a dead wall.
NYSSA: Then we've come the wrong way.
DOCTOR: Nyssa, do you think I don't know my own Tardis?
NYSSA: How long is it since we were here? Five Earth months? That's a long time.
DOCTOR: And it's not right. The ship feels used, and the engines sound wrong.
NYSSA: It probably just needs a little fine-tuning, that's all.
DOCTOR: And there used to be a rattle from the control mounting whenever we took off. It's been there for years.
NYSSA: Yes, I remember that.
DOCTOR: Well, now it's gone. And there are other rattles, new rattles, creaks.
NYSSA: Oh, even worse.
DOCTOR: Exactly. The whole ship's heaving like a storm-tossed galleon. Can't you hear it?
NYSSA: I think you're exaggerating. Come on, let's get you a cup of tea.
DOCTOR: That boy.
NYSSA: Doctor...
DOCTOR: Thomas Brewster, the boy who stole my Tardis.
NYSSA: He borrowed it.
DOCTOR: He marooned us. Scattered off on his own, going goodness knows where, doing goodness knows what. Though I doubt goodness had much to do with it. And it takes a poor lost ghost to bring him back to heel, his tail between his legs.
NYSSA: He's very young.
DOCTOR: Oh well, that makes all the difference.
NYSSA: Tea, Doctor.
DOCTOR: If there's any tea left. Hang on. Hang on, this door.
NYSSA: This one? What about it?
DOCTOR: It doesn't belong.
NYSSA: Yes, Doctor.
DOCTOR: There shouldn't be a door here, not just here.
NYSSA: Then let's see what's inside.
DOCTOR: Don't touch! We don't know where it goes. It could lead inside the Power House, or directly into the Vortex.
NYSSA: Hardly likely, is it?
DOCTOR: Better safe than sorry.
NYSSA: Oh, at this rate we'll be here all day. Stand back.
DOCTOR: Nyssa!
NYSSA: The control room. But that's impossible.
THOMAS: Hello. Didn't expect you two strollers back so quick.
NYSSA: We can't be back here. Not from there.
DOCTOR: Not unless someone's been messing about with the inner dimensions.
THOMAS: I ain't done nothing. Don't look at me.
DOCTOR: Funny, that. I don't see anyone else to look at. Maybe he has something more to tell us, eh Nyssa?
THOMAS: Oi, now, don't you start.
DOCTOR: Such as where he's been all the time he stranded us in a primitive polluted den of thieving and vice...
THOMAS: That's my home you're talking about.
NYSSA: Doctor, Thomas may have left us for five months...
DOCTOR: Abandoned.
THOMAS: Just Brewster, Miss.
NYSSA: But in the Tardis's own relative time-stream, he might only have been away for five minutes.
THOMAS: Yeah, that's right. Wink of the old peepers.
DOCTOR: Not from the accumulation of evidence on offer. So where have you been, and what have you done to my...? Is that my shirt you're wearing?
NYSSA: I wondered when you'd notice.
DOCTOR: It is. You're wearing my shirt.
THOMAS: I had to wear something. Sides, I ain't no lully triper. There was a whole cupboard full. All different sizes. Can't all be yours though, can they?
NYSSA: I'm sure you could spare one.
DOCTOR: That's not the point. Not content with hijacking my ship, he helps himself to... Nyssa, where are you going?
NYSSA: I'm going to get you that cup of tea. Talk to Brewster, Doctor, not me.
DOCTOR: Nyssa, be careful - the dimensions out there aren't...
DOCTOR: Stable.
THOMAS: So...
DOCTOR: All right. All right, so I may have been hasty. Launching out into Time and Space on your own can be a unnerving experience, downright terrifying actually. That doesn't change, however long you've travelled.
THOMAS: I'm sorry, Doctor. It is an amazing ship though, the Tardis. Your Tardis.
DOCTOR: Yes. I think so too. Right. First we're running a full systems fault check to see what the damage is. Now then... (beeps) That's odd. The fault location system's on the blink.
THOMAS: Really?
DOCTOR: That shouldn't happen. Let's take a look down here. What? Where's it gone? It's vanished. The fault locator unit. Someone's taken it out. Brewster?
THOMAS: Me? Now, hang on a mo.
NYSSA: Doctor, the food machine...
DOCTOR: Not now, Nyssa.
NYSSA: But it's gone.
DOCTOR: Gone?
THOMAS: Blimey, what was that?
DOCTOR: I wouldn't know, Brewster. You tell me.
VUYOKI: 4 Can you find me, look behind me, in the dark before the dawn. Do not leave me, please retrieve me, I am waiting to be...
VUYOKI: Born. Who's there?
LUCOR: [OC]: My Lady Vuyoki?
VUYOKI: Go away. I'm waiting to be spirited to my new life.
LUCOR: [OC]: My Lady, I come to your ship bearing a message from Commander Gammades.
VUYOKI: Oh, not again. You may look in upon me.
VUYOKI: Careful with the lid, idiot. This bridal urn has served my family for generations.
LUCOR: Forgive me, my Lady.
VUYOKI: You find it amusing that I live inside a jar?
LUCOR: No, my Lady.
VUYOKI: What about your tiny brain rattling round your empty skull? That's much funnier. So, what have you brought? A salutation, or gifts?
LUCOR: The Commander's message. Here.
VUYOKI: All right, all right, stand away.
LUCOR: My Lady.
VUYOKI: Further. Further! A lady must breathe. No, don't go, idiot. Wait for my reply.
GAMMADES: [OC]: My Lady Vuyoki, why so coy?
VUYOKI: Coy?
GAMMADES: [OC]: We find ourselves, you and I, caught in a net of eternal twilight, thrown together on this gods-forsaken rock...
VUYOKI: Oh, really.
GAMMADES: [OC]: It clutches at us and holds us tight...
VUYOKI: There's nothing worse than an amateur poet.
GAMMADES: [OC]: Our ship is sound. We seek to cut her free from the coral that binds us all here, so let our shelter be yours also.
VUYOKI: Shelter? Oh, how touching. You. Yes, you.
LUCOR: Huh?
VUYOKI: How does this grubby object work? How do I send back my answer? Well? Come on, I can't do everything myself.
NYSSA: I can't make out these readings. They don't correlate.
DOCTOR: Nope, none of them do. Right, that should hold.
THOMAS: String? You're trusting yourself to a ball of string?
DOCTOR: Bailer twine. Unwound, it should get me as far as the auxiliary junctions. If I tug the line twice, start hauling me back.
NYSSA: Are you sure that's necessary? The corridors were stable just now.
DOCTOR: But they weren't before that.
NYSSA: That's true.
DOCTOR: The fact is, we don't know how much damage Brewster's done, do we?
THOMAS: I keep telling you, I ain't done nothing.
DOCTOR: Right Nyssa, open the inner door, would you?
NYSSA: It looks safe enough.
DOCTOR: Let's hope so. Remember, two tugs on the line.
NYSSA: Please be careful.
DOCTOR: And don't let him touch anything. I'll be back as quick as I can.
NYSSA: Brewster?
THOMAS: Don't you start.
NYSSA: Look, I thought we were friends. The food machine and the fault locator, is that all that's missing?
THOMAS: How should I know?
NYSSA: Because I think there's a lot else that isn't here any more. The whole dimensional structure of the Tardis has destabilised.
THOMAS: Don't ask me. I belong in the gutter with the rest of the slush.
NYSSA: That's silly. I wish you'd tell us where you went.
THOMAS: None of your business.
NYSSA: I'm trying to help. I Know the Doctor's angry, but if you tell him the truth he'll understand.
THOMAS: What do you care? Swanning about, giving yourself airs like a princess. I know a proper lady, see, and she owes me a cartload of favours.
NYSSA: Is that someone you've met? Brewster, where have you been?
THOMAS: Hell and back.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Nyssa, help me!
NYSSA: Doctor?
THOMAS: Look at the passageway. It's all sliding through itself.
NYSSA: The dimensions are folding in. We've got to get him out of there.
VUYOKI: [OC]: Commander Gammades, I thank you for your most generous offer - which I fear I must decline.
GAMMADES: But why must you?
VUYOKI: [OC]: As you say, you are rough voyagers.
GAMMADES: Oh...
VUYOKI: [OC]: And a lady of Marabou must maintain her quality. You see, dear Gammades, you would never be more than a servant to me. And of course, I would never desire to demean your standing.
GAMMADES: What standing? We're all of us shipwrecked on this accursed rock.
VUYOKI: [OC]: So, I must wait alone for Old Birth to take me, and lament how you can never be part of my newborn life. (laughs) There. Finished. How do I switch this thing off?
GAMMADES: What spirit she has. No, my Lady. Such determined grace only fans the flames of my ardour, and one day soon, we shall be as one.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Nyssa, help me!
NYSSA: Brewster, help me pull him back.
THOMAS: I am. Can't see nothing down there. It's black as pitch.
NYSSA: Doctor, hold on!
DOCTOR: [OC]: Nyssa!
NYSSA: His hand. Oh, it's freezing cold!
DOCTOR: [OC]: Help me!
NYSSA: I couldn't hold him. He's gone, Brewster. The Doctor's gone.
THOMAS: Not if I can help it he ain't.
NYSSA: No, Brewster, don't.
THOMAS: Af! It's freezing. Can hardly feel my fin. Oh, come on, Doctor, grab my hand.
NYSSA: Thomas, come away. You'll die.
THOMAS: I can't let him go, not like this. It ain't right. Ah! I've got him. I've got him!
NYSSA: Pull. Keep pulling. Doctor, you're safe.
DOCTOR: Just about. Brewster? Was that you who pulled me clear?
THOMAS: Both of us, Nyssa and me.
DOCTOR: Thank you. I, I'm sorry, I ... I couldn't - reach the junctions. I seem to be covered in ice.
NYSSA: Here, put your coat on. Brewster, rub that arm or you'll get frostbite.
THOMAS: Yes, Miss.
NYSSA: And I think we'd better shut this.
DOCTOR: Oh! The relative structure of the Tardis is in flux. It's all breaking down. We can't leave the control room.
THOMAS: There's still the doors to the outside.
NYSSA: Not while we're in flight. But we could try the conceptual geometer. It maps out the Tardis's interior. If we could access that...
DOCTOR: My first thought too. (beep) But wouldn't you know it, the geometer's not registering either. Where is it, Brewster? Still in the ship, or did you sell it off for cheap gin and a pie?
NYSSA: Doctor, stop hectoring him. It isn't helping.
DOCTOR: Perhaps not, but it makes me feel better. Now, if I can just find out where the Tardis has been,
DOCTOR: may be our only chance. Well, there's a miracle. The memory bank's still intact.
THOMAS: What's he doing?
DOCTOR: Getting worried now, are you?
NYSSA: The Doctor's checking the Tardis's recent flights.
DOCTOR: And destinations.
THOMAS: That's private. I don't go checking up on you.
DOCTOR: Right then, back journey number one.
THOMAS: Don't go there, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Go where? These coordinates don't even add up.
THOMAS: Just don't, that's all.
NYSSA: There's no spatial or temporal locations.
DOCTOR: Exactly. They don't exist. But if the Tardis has been before, she'll remember.
NYSSA: She's barely holding together.
THOMAS: Doctor, I'm begging you, please.
DOCTOR: Let's go.
GAMMADES: Lucor, what's that racket?
LUCOR: Not sure, Commander. It suddenly started up. I'm trying to pinpoint its source.
GAMMADES: It's the beacon. It must be. Where's Eumachus?
LUCOR: His orbit's due round any moment. Horizon at dawn point.
GAMMADES: Hmm?
LUCOR: And... up he rises. You could run a clock off him.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Hello down there!
LUCOR: If only we could reach him.
GAMMADES: I told you, it's the beacon. It's working at last. And you thought it was a bad trade. Twenty goldoons for the first man to sight rescue.
LUCOR: There's a proper swell getting up on the surface.
GAMMADES: Future and past in ferment. Deep gods, I need a gale of fresh Time blowing in my face.
LUCOR: Looks like it's building up into a real Time storm. Heavy weather ahead, lads. Everyone, below decks, ready to batten the force-shields.
GAMMADES: Maybe it'll blow the Ruhk away.
LUCOR: Something's coming through.
GAMMADES: I know that's sound. It's him. He's coming back. It's the Doctor.
NYSSA: Systems under stress. Imminent structural collapse. What's that noise?
DOCTOR: A distress signal. I don't believe it, it's another Tardis.
NYSSA: Another Tardis?
DOCTOR: Brewster, perhaps you could shed some light.
THOMAS: I don't know what you mean.
NYSSA: Doctor, the inner wall's rupturing. It won't hold.
DOCTOR: I know that signal. It's not another Tardis, it's this one. That's the alarm on the missing conceptual geometer. It's calling to us.
NYSSA: It can't be. Unless it's wreckers, drawing us in.
DOCTOR: We could home in on that signal manually, if we last that long.
NYSSA: Too late. We're on collision course.
THOMAS: The walls!
DOCTOR: Hang on tight.
DOCTOR: Out, both of you.
NYSSA: The interior's collapsing.
DOCTOR: Get clear!
THOMAS: What happened?
DOCTOR: It's gone.
THOMAS: Gone? What do you mean, gone?
DOCTOR: The whole internal structure of the Tardis just imploded.
NYSSA: But there must be some way to recover it.
DOCTOR: You saw for yourself. The interior dimensions compacted. They crushed down to a single knot, a
DOCTOR: nothing. My Tardis is dead.
THOMAS: It can't be, I mean, surely we can do something?
DOCTOR: We can't. It's over.
THOMAS: What?
NYSSA: Brewster. I think the Doctor would like to be on his own for a few moments. Over here.
THOMAS: Is he all right?
NYSSA: He's in shock. The Tardis was his home for a long, long time. He's lost an old friend.
THOMAS: I can see that. Look, we can't stay here.
NYSSA: It doesn't look terribly welcoming, does it? It’s so airless and barren, like the surface of an asteroid. You've been here before, haven't you? What happened? Why are you so scared?
THOMAS: I'm not. Oh, you wouldn't understand.
NYSSA: Well, if you won't talk to me, at least speak to the Doctor.
DOCTOR: An excellent suggestion, Nyssa. I'd be most interested in what Master Brewster has to say. If he has a mind to speak, that is.
THOMAS: I don't know.
NYSSA: Maybe it's better if I'm not here.
DOCTOR: Don't wander too far.
NYSSA: I won't.
DOCTOR: Now then, Brewster, what about this place?
THOMAS: Dunno. You can see, can't ya? It's a rock - no sun, no stars. The sort of place the Beak send you when you get transported.
DOCTOR: It might as well be. Do you know what this rock is, Brewster? It's a reef of space corals, stuck in a bubble of existence where nothing can exist. But how it got here, I couldn't say. And those lights up there are the energetic patterns of the Time Vortex outside playing across the surface of the bubble. Like being underwater, isn't it?
THOMAS: Never was much cop at swimming.
DOCTOR: But it's not deserted, is it? You see? Shards of pottery, scattered all over. Not old either, from the patterns, I'd say. Umian, possibly Marabou. One of the late dynasties.
THOMAS: I told you, I don't know nothing.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: (laughs) Hello down there!
THOMAS: What's that?
DOCTOR: Up there, by the surface. A man in a spacesuit. He's waving. Some friend of yours, perhaps. Hello up there.
THOMAS: Don't do that.
DOCTOR: Why not? Scared of attracting trouble?
GAMMADES: Doctor, is that you?
THOMAS: Too late.
DOCTOR: Who are these people? Someone I should know?
GAMMADES: Hook them. Well, well. Who's your friend, Doctor? Another liar?
THOMAS: Scarce it. Run!
LUCOR: Oh no you don't, lad. Not that way.
GAMMADES: Well, Doctor. We thought you'd abandoned us. But no one ever escapes this place, eh? Not even you. What shall we do with him, eh, lads? Stake him out on the rocks and leave him for the night- winged Ruhk to feed on?
DOCTOR: The Ruhk?
NYSSA: Hello? Is anyone there? My name is Nyssa. I mean you no harm.
RUHK: Nyssa. I smell your fear.
NYSSA: Who... who are you?
RUHK: I was the Ruhk.
NYSSA: You were the Ruhk? So who are you now?
RUHK: I am the hunter, and there is no escape.

elements.text: [Part Two]
You're the last person we expected, Doctor.
I'm sorry. Have we met before?
Pin it, Blondie. Commander Gammades was talking to the Doctor.
The Doctor?
Mister G. Er, how do you do again.
You lied, Doctor. You tricked us.
Lied? Me?
Ah! The Doctor. Yes, of course.
I said, pin it.
Absolutely. You speak to the Doctor. He's the expert.
We trusted you, Doctor. So you traded us damaged goods and deserted us.
Come on, Mister G, would I do that to you?
You lured my ship to this rock and stranded us.
Stranded? Never. I went away for a bit that's all. I was always coming back.
Well done, Brewster. Welcome to your world.
Open up your Tardis.
What?
We're commandeering it. I know there's cabin space inside for all my crew.
Now, let's not be too hasty, eh?
Open it up!
Oh, come on, Mister G, look. I Know we ain't as friendly as two inkle weavers, but I wasn't just gonna leave ya.
You weren't, eh?
Course not. In fact, I brung you some help. That's why I went off to fetch.
Help? This one?
Blondie here. He's the one in charge. He's the one who knows it all. If I were you, I'd talk to him.
Come back, Doctor, you little...
Brewster, come back!
You men, get after the Doctor. Well, go on. Get on with it.
The men won't go, sir, not down the gully. That's where the Ruhk lives.
Look, what is this Ruhk? Some sort of indigenous species?
A damned carrion bird. It preys on us all.
None of my crew goes down there. Too dangerous.
I have a friend down there. I need to make sure she's safe.
You're going nowhere.
The Ruhk is the Doctor's problem now. So he brought you as help, did he? You must have a key to his box of tricks.
Only the Doctor has a key, I'm afraid. He seldom gives it to... companions.
Doesn't trust you either, eh? Lucor, put a man on guard here.
Sir.
And bring our new friend back to the Gamma.
There is no escape.
What do you want?
Your fear grows. Be afraid in your dark.
I'm not afraid.
Fetch the beacon.
Let go of me.
The beacon. It sings this place alive. Sings the blinding dark.
The blinding dark? Can't you see me, then?
In my mind, as I crawl, I read your fear.
I understand. You're blind. I'm very sorry for you, but...
This place, its symmetry, dark, beguiling. But of endless light I flew into its trap. Hard, heavy, crushing. Let us pull it apart!
My arm, you're hurting me.
No more song. No more beacon song. Too many will die.
I don't know where the beacon is.
Find the Commander. It lies with him.
I don't know who he is either.
The goats know what is coming. They were born to the sacrifice.
I'll find the Commander if I can, I promise.
Find the beacon, Nyssa, or the dark crushes us all.
Suspend the clearance work, men.
The hull won't keep itself free of coral.
Really? How fast does it grow?
The Doctor's brought us his Tardis. Lucor, we'll soon be away from here. An extra round of grog for the crew. We're going home!
You're not abandoning the Gamma, sir?
We'll salvage what we can. Well, come on, damn you, cheer. Our curse is ended. The gods are happy again.
Your crew don't seem convinced, and you still haven't found the Doctor. Look, my friend Nyssa's out there. I really think...
If you don't pin it, Blondie, I'll chop your tongue out to bung the holes in my sandals. You're going in the hold, for safe-keeping.
Lucor? Remember a hero's laws. He's my guest and comes with me.
Thank you, Commander.
Besides, we need to find the Doctor and this Nyssa. They're your friends, aren't they? They won't go without you. Come.
That's if the Ruhk don't find 'em first.
My Lady? (taps on urn) Lady V, it's me. You still in there? (lid moved) Not at home, then. Still got your jewels, though, so you can't be far.
Please, help yourself.
Oh, Lady Vuyoki. I'm back, ma'am.
Oh. Doctor Brewster, it's you.
Didn't think I'd desert you, did ya? I'm the bad farthing, always turning up.
But it takes such a long time from one always to the next. How much longer must I endure this place?
Did you miss me?
I've had more attentive callers.
With presents, like the ones I brought ya?
What have you brought this time?
Well, not so much as it happens. Fact is, I'm stony just now, cleared out, pockets to let.
You've brought me nothing?
I'll bring you something soon, I swear. You've still got your jewels, though, and the food.
Oh, it makes the endless days of my after-death bearable. I sit in my bridal urn, chew on a dried bar of porpoise scrapings, and contemplate my next life.
I thought my life was over too. But it ain't, not yet. There's ways back to the world, ma'am.
There's only one way. We're all dead here, Doctor Brewster. Each condemned to our particular torments. All waiting to be reborn.
What's that? Someone's coming.
The Ruhk. Help me, Doctor. Secure my lid.
Don't you fret, ma'am, I'm here. I'll soon see him off. I hope.
Here's my cabin. Find a place where you can.
Thank you, Commander. Very cosy. Is this a picture of your family?
My sons. And if I'm not home soon they'll be as old as I am.
One of the perils of time travel.
No matter. Let's salute our imminent departure from this rock.
Ah. I think a celebration may be a bit premature.
You know, I've nothing against you, Blondie. Not yet. But I don't like the company you keep. Once we find the Doctor we'll open up his Tardis and be away.
And abandon your magnificent ship? These Calimeran galleys are famous, you know. You were the classical pioneers of trans-temporal voyaging.

Oh, I don't give up the Gamma lightly. We're heroes, seeking adventure across the ages, returning from the sack of Shermanzi and the Wineskin Cloud. Oh, that was a campaign, I can tell you. I’ve press reports somewhere. I slew the blood-pocked Hippodile of Yoth in hand-to-tooth combat, it was terrific. And when we left, the ship was heavy with booty, but as we slid between the shoals of Time we heard a cry for help.
Let me guess. A beacon.

There's always the danger of Sirens. But it might have been some wretched mariner, cast adrift in eternity, so we altered course, following the call, and before we knew it, we were aground, wrecked on this uncharted reef.
This equipment here. It's a temporal navigation unit. Where exactly did you get it?
Oh, I traded it with your friend the Doctor. He was here on the reef already touting for business with his Tardis set out like a market stall.
He sold you stuff from the Tardis?
Hmm.
How much did he charge?
Plenty. Cost us a large chunk of our treasure trove.
Indeed?
And I'm damned if any of it works.
This bit won't. Outside its home it's about as system-compatible as a biscuit in a waterfall. What
else did he sell you? A fault locator?
Useless object.
A food machine?
Food? Now, that we could have done with. Oh, plenty of other stuff, though. That beacon, the one that lured us here in the first place. He said it might attract rescue.
Ah.
And then he saw his chance. Off he went, and we were stranded.
But it worked. Here we are, except the beacon isn't a beacon.
What do you mean?
It's the conceptual geometer from my Tardis. Your so-called beacon is its alarm.
Your Tardis? It's yours?
All this equipment is mine, Commander, and I want it back.
Tough! It was paid for.
You'll get a full refund and apology. Now, where's the geometer?
The beacon? It's not here. It's out of reach.
Commander, I thought my ship was dead, but with the geometer it might still be rescuable.
(laughs) Oh, that Doctor, eh? He's tricked you too.
I think this has gone far enough.
Here, where, where are you off to?
How big is this reef?
It's not big, but still growing.
Then I'm going for a walk. You can come too. The exercise will do you good.
Hello? Anyone there?
Nyssa. it's you.
Brewster.
Keep the door shut.
Door closes.
I'm glad it's you. This place ain't safe. Gives me the jiggers.
I thought you were with the Doctor.
Oh, I was. He sent me to find you.
Then what are you doing in here?
What are you doing with a flock of goats, eh? Got a new job as a shepherdess?
They were showing me the way.
The goats?
I'm looking for the Commander. Do you know him?
No. Why? Who have you been talking to?
Listen, Brewster, it's important. Is this the Commander's ship?
How should I know?
Hmm. Well, it's broken, so it must have crashed. I wonder what all these big jars are for?
I wouldn't touch 'em if I were you.
Urn lid moves.
Oh.
And who is this?
Er... My Lady Vuyoki. May I introduce...
Not introduce. How vulgar. Present her to me.
My name is Nyssa of Traken. And you are...?
Nyssa, may I present my Lady Vuyoki.
I'm far from yours, Doctor Brewster.
Doctor? Oh, this is the lady you told me so much about.
Did he? What did he say?
Me? I didn't say nothing.
He said how real you were. A real lady.
Oh.
But he's easily impressed. And all your jewellery. Is that real too? Must be very cramped living in that jar.
Is this your gift, Brewster? A slave to serve me in my confinement until Old Birth comes to lead me to my new life?
Old Birth? Who's that?
Quiet. In my old life we fed new slaves on mud so they knew their place. And they didn't speak out of turn.
Brewster, please explain to that lady that I am no servant of hers.
What?
The truth is, ma'am, Nyssa's not a skiwy. She's a... she's a friend of mine.
Ah, yes. I could tell. You make such a charming match.
The Ruhk.
It must be following me.
And you brought it here? You led that misshapen fiend to my inviolable sanctuary? Curse you, you worm. The Ruhk will kill us all.

When I was newborn, they took me to the Oracle of Calimera. She sat deep in the smoky belly of the world, and foretold my death in glorious battle. My first toy was a sword, and all through school and training, they said I'd be a mighty hero. But I'll never meet my great doom now. At the burning of the Sable Empire, a wounded Sphinx came prowling through the field of dead, the way they do. She found me where I lay bleeding and cursed me to eternal life. Do you think there's a worse fate for a hero? I was trained to die in combat, not live for ever. I'm pinned like an insect between the beating wings of prophecy and curse, and they will tear me apart.
In my experience, Commander, fortune tellers, even Sphinxes, only ever say half of what they mean. Here, lean on me.
Thanks. So we were... we were trapped outside Time in a bubble of endless now. The gods, they love to mock us, don't they? But with your Tardis we've hope again.
I told you, we need the geometer back first.
You know, we've not sacrificed since the Ruhk stole our goats.
It stole them? So it's rational, not just a wild beast loose on the reef.
That's a hundred and thirty days now. I already owe twelve goats on the tally, or their equal. No wonder the gods are cross.
I don't hold with blood sacrifices. Come on, careful, it’s steep down here.
My dear chap, how in Deep Heaven do you get anything done?
I managed, up until now.
I have dependents.
Yes. Of course, your sons at home.
My sons, my crew. And one other. Look. There, see? Between the ridges. That's where she dwells.
The wreck of a spaceship. How many survivors?
Just one. A lonely lady, cool as pearl, fiery as the sky. My Lady Vuyoki of Marabou.
Grand Marabou? How did she get here? Her dynasty rules the stars at the far end of Time to yours.
She dazzles the reef like a comet with her beauty. I vowed to rescue her from this damnable prison.
I wish you hadn't done that.
Come. There's the Doctor's Tardis.
My Tardis.
Oh, if you say so. And over the next crest is the Gamma.
So we've walked for an hour in a straight line right round the circumference of the reef, and we're back where we started.
The Ruhk. It's hunting again. It's always hunting.
It's just outside.
What are you doing? Nyssa.
I'm going to talk to it.
No.
You'll speak to that monster?
Why not? It has feelings too.
Hate, anger.
It can't see. It's lost and confused.
Oh, poor thing. Yes, perhaps you should go out to it.
No, Nyssa. I won't let you. It ain't safe.
But she wants to.
No.
I'm surrounded by heroes.
Brewster, let me go. I promised I'd help the Ruhk.
It knows we're ‘ere.
It knows she's here. It followed her trail.
Well, it's not going to get her. Come on, ma'am. There must be another way out.
There is. Through here. This leads to the hold, which has a loading port. From there, just follow the gully upwards. If the rocks haven't overgrown it, it leads towards the Gamma.
The what?
Tell you later. Now, get through there, please.
Oh, very well.
What about you, ma'am?
I've dealt with the Ruhk before. It won't have forgotten. Now, go.
But ma'am...
Leave me. Out, out! And don't hurry back. And now for you.
Door opens.

Hello, monster. Oh, she's gone, your friend. How she laughed at you. Called you a misshapen fiend. You poor thing. But if you hurry you'll soon catch her. I've sent her out the back, to where your nest is. There's no escape for you now, Nyssa of Traken.
I don't understand. I told Lucor to leave a guard on this Tardis of yours.
Maybe he didn't want to stand in one place for too long. Look at this. The coral's already growing up the sides.
One day the reef will fill the whole bubble.
I don't doubt it.
Still no sign of the Doctor either. You're his friend, where is he?
Commander, there's something I should have told you.
About what?
About this place, and me. The fact is...
[OC]: Hello down there!
And here he is, right on time.
Who is that?
His name was Eumachus. Every galley has apprentice hero.
A trainee scheme?
Well, the little fool was trying to get that beacon the Doctor sold us to work.
I told you, it's not a beacon, it's a conceptual geometer.
And then the Ruhk attacked, and Eumachus cut his own line, touched the surface of the bubble and got pinned to the sky, poor lad. That's where your geometer thingy is, up there, way out of reach.
Commander.
Tardis door opens.
You said you didn't have a key.
I said only the Doctor has a key, which is true, most of the time. Go on, take a look. This was my Tardis, and my home.
But... it's dark. It's like a void. It was all space and lights before.
It's dead, or as good as. It has no dimensional structure, not until I get that geometer back. I'm the Doctor, Commander. Me, not Brewster.
You?
Brewster's just a little mudlark with a knack for trouble. He made a fool of me. He stole my Tardis and caused all this inconvenience for you.
[OC]: Hello down there!

This reality bubble we're trapped in, it's generated by the conceptual geometer Brewster sold you. The geometer we can't reach. Time and Space are all churned up here. It takes just one stray polyp of space coral on the Tardis shell, and you've soon got a whole reef to wreck ships and strand innocent lives.
So... it's your fault?
That's right. It's my negligence that's trapped us all.
Brewster, stop. This can't be right.
Lady V said to follow the gully.
But it doesn't lead anywhere. It's a dead end.
She said the rocks might have tangled over, and look - one load of tangled-over rocks.
It looks more like a... a nest to me. Brewster, this isn't right, and she knew it wasn't.
Goats bleating.
Something's coming.
It's only the goats. I expect they followed us.
The Ruhk. I'll speak to it.
No, get down. Hide yourself before we're scrubbed.
Quiet, children. I hear you, Nyssa. I smell you. You who betrayed me.
My Lady Vuyoki, are you there?
Door slides open.
Oh, it's you, Commander. Do you ever take no for an answer?
Door slides closed.
But I've brought you something.
Yes?
A visitor.
Oh. Well, it's one caller after another today. You'd best come in.
Thank you. My Lady, this is the Doctor.
Another Doctor? Oh!
Lady Vuyoki, how do you do?
Is it over? Is my wait over at last.
Well, I, er...

Oh, Lords. Spirit forgive me. You may cloak yourself in mortal guise to shield me from your glory, but I Know you. I've spent every solitudinous moment in contemplating my past sins. I'm washed pure of my old life, and ready to be led to my new one.
Actually, I was looking for two friends of mine.
But you are he? You must be. He who leads the unborn rejoicing to their new lives. The all-knowing spirit whom we call Old Birth.
I think you're mistaking me for someone else. About my friends...
Friends? Oh. You mean that other brat Doctor and his drab little drudge.
Brewster and Nyssa.
Oh, I think they passed through. I was at my devotions at the time.
My Lady, those jewels you're wearing...
They are mine.
They were mine first. Booty from a sack of the Sable Empire. How did you come by them?
They were a gift. People like to give me things. I'm appreciated.
It was that wretched boy, wasn't it?
Yes, Brewster's at that sort of age, I'm afraid.
What else have you got in here?
Leave that! My bridal urn cannot be defiled.
Bridal? Looks more like a jar you'd be buried in. These hieroglyphs are very interesting.
Leave it alone.
Fascinating. Does this represent your sun?
I said leave it!
My Lady.
What?
All the dark jewels match your eyes. You are intoxicating.
Oh!
No, no, no, don't laugh. My offer of shelter still stands. How can you live alone, no company, no food?
Oh, go away. Go on, go. And take him with you. I have my prayers to say.
What about my friends?
Tedious in the extreme. I dismissed them. They were trying to hide here from the Ruhk.
You threw them out? Well, where are they now?
You are here. But where is here? Children. Where are they?
Don't move. He ain't got eyes.
I promised.
Your thoughts betray you, Nyssa of Traken. Here you are!
It's no betrayal. I had no time.
Time crushes us all.
Get away from her!
Brewster!
The beacon must not sing.
(approaching) Please, leave my friends alone.
Doctor!
Nyssa. I'm relieved to see you. Brewster, are you all right?
Fine, just winded.
Good. And you're the Ruhk, I presume. I'm the Doctor.
It's trapped and alone. It doesn't belong here. In fact, I don't think it belongs in this dimension.
A para-dimensional being, you mean? That would explain a great deal. Listen, I understand why you're scared. We're all trapped here, but I'll help you if I can.
More promises.
Where do you come from?
Not here. An eternal everness of flying free. We never touch the ground.
I'm sorry. Our dimensions must bind you cruelly.
They beguile and crush.
Trust me. I'll get you away, I give you my word.
(distant) Get down, all of you, now!
Come on, lads.
Net away!
That's got it. Right in the snare. Well done, lads.
Commander, what are you doing?
Draw it in.
Let it go.
Watch that line. Steady!
At last. Ha ha, what a prize!
Tighten it up there.
Let the Ruhk go.
Physter, Thiades, had out the goats. Back to the ship.
It's a living creature. Set it free now.
Oh, stop moaning, Doctor. It's all your fault in the first place. Come on now, let's cheer up the old gods with a sacrifice to remember. Back to the ship.
No, Commander, I won't let that happen.
Like hell you won't.
Punch.
Doctor!
Hey!
And no lip from you two either. Tonight the gods get drunk on blood, and tomorrow we're going home.
Cheers.
Drunken revels.
Not joining the party, Blondie? Goat meat too strong for ya?
I would if I wasn't chained to the mast, Lucor. Call off the sacrifices, the gods don't care about spilt blood.
The gods suit themselves, as long as I don't lose my ship.
You won't. Only fools lose their ships. Let the Ruhk go. Let's get the beacon back.
Not a chance. The lad's got it. Eumachus, up on the surface, out of reach.
What about your harpoon?
What? This little beauty. No. I ain't gonna skewer him.
You could attach a net, like the one you used on the Ruhk.
I tried that already. It didn't stick. Let him float in peace, poor lad. Round and round. At least he never stops laughing.
Of course. Sorry to bother you, enjoy your party. Brewster, did you get it?
Easy. He's too soused to notice a dipper. Here. One key for the harpoon, and one for your chains. Hold still.
Thank you. Now, let's prime the harpoon. Insert the key.
Like this?
Perfect. Good. It's auto-loading. Set to stun, I think. That should knock the geometer out of Eumachus's grasp. Now, where's our orbiting apprentice gone?
Doctor?
Not now, Nyssa.
What's happening? You're not trying to get the geometer back?
And solve everything in one giant leap. Yes, I'm afraid so, it's an unfortunate habit I have.
But the Ruhk begged us not to activate the alarm.
There he is.
[OC}: Hello down there!
No. It pleaded. There'll be more trouble.
Hoi. What's all the fuss?
The whole reef may collapse, but if we can get the geometer back inside the Tardis ... Ah. Got him right in my sights.
Commander. The Doctor. He's loose!
What?
Doctor, no.
Sorry, Nyssa. (harpoon fired) Oh. Missed. So close.
What are you playing at, disturbing the boy.
The beacon.
The bolt must have reactivated it.
Look at the sky. There's a storm coming.
Batten the forceshields. Storm warning.
Aye, aye, Commander.
Ruhks.
Hundreds of 'em.
Monsters ahoy!
We'll be over-run.
The whole Ruhkery, falling from the sky like rain. They're beaching.
You idiot, you've led them here, and now they're going to kill us all.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
GAMMADES: You're the last person we expected, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I'm sorry. Have we met before?
LUCOR: Pin it, Blondie. Commander Gammades was talking to the Doctor.
DOCTOR: The Doctor?
THOMAS: Mister G. Er, how do you do again.
GAMMADES: You lied, Doctor. You tricked us.
THOMAS: Lied? Me?
DOCTOR: Ah! The Doctor. Yes, of course.
LUCOR: I said, pin it.
DOCTOR: Absolutely. You speak to the Doctor. He's the expert.
GAMMADES: We trusted you, Doctor. So you traded us damaged goods and deserted us.
THOMAS: Come on, Mister G, would I do that to you?
GAMMADES: You lured my ship to this rock and stranded us.
THOMAS: Stranded? Never. I went away for a bit that's all. I was always coming back.
DOCTOR: Well done, Brewster. Welcome to your world.
GAMMADES: Open up your Tardis.
THOMAS: What?
GAMMADES: We're commandeering it. I know there's cabin space inside for all my crew.
THOMAS: Now, let's not be too hasty, eh?
GAMMADES: Open it up!
THOMAS: Oh, come on, Mister G, look. I Know we ain't as friendly as two inkle weavers, but I wasn't just gonna leave ya.
GAMMADES: You weren't, eh?
THOMAS: Course not. In fact, I brung you some help. That's why I went off to fetch.
LUCOR: Help? This one?
THOMAS: Blondie here. He's the one in charge. He's the one who knows it all. If I were you, I'd talk to him.
GAMMADES: Come back, Doctor, you little...
DOCTOR: Brewster, come back!
GAMMADES: You men, get after the Doctor. Well, go on. Get on with it.
LUCOR: The men won't go, sir, not down the gully. That's where the Ruhk lives.
DOCTOR: Look, what is this Ruhk? Some sort of indigenous species?
GAMMADES: A damned carrion bird. It preys on us all.
LUCOR: None of my crew goes down there. Too dangerous.
DOCTOR: I have a friend down there. I need to make sure she's safe.
LUCOR: You're going nowhere.
GAMMADES: The Ruhk is the Doctor's problem now. So he brought you as help, did he? You must have a key to his box of tricks.
DOCTOR: Only the Doctor has a key, I'm afraid. He seldom gives it to... companions.
GAMMADES: Doesn't trust you either, eh? Lucor, put a man on guard here.
LUCOR: Sir.
GAMMADES: And bring our new friend back to the Gamma.
RUHK: There is no escape.
NYSSA: What do you want?
RUHK: Your fear grows. Be afraid in your dark.
NYSSA: I'm not afraid.
RUHK: Fetch the beacon.
NYSSA: Let go of me.
RUHK: The beacon. It sings this place alive. Sings the blinding dark.
NYSSA: The blinding dark? Can't you see me, then?
RUHK: In my mind, as I crawl, I read your fear.
NYSSA: I understand. You're blind. I'm very sorry for you, but...
RUHK: This place, its symmetry, dark, beguiling. But of endless light I flew into its trap. Hard, heavy, crushing. Let us pull it apart!
NYSSA: My arm, you're hurting me.
RUHK: No more song. No more beacon song. Too many will die.
NYSSA: I don't know where the beacon is.
RUHK: Find the Commander. It lies with him.
NYSSA: I don't know who he is either.
RUHK: The goats know what is coming. They were born to the sacrifice.
NYSSA: I'll find the Commander if I can, I promise.
RUHK: Find the beacon, Nyssa, or the dark crushes us all.
GAMMADES: Suspend the clearance work, men.
LUCOR: The hull won't keep itself free of coral.
DOCTOR: Really? How fast does it grow?
GAMMADES: The Doctor's brought us his Tardis. Lucor, we'll soon be away from here. An extra round of grog for the crew. We're going home!
LUCOR: You're not abandoning the Gamma, sir?
GAMMADES: We'll salvage what we can. Well, come on, damn you, cheer. Our curse is ended. The gods are happy again.
DOCTOR: Your crew don't seem convinced, and you still haven't found the Doctor. Look, my friend Nyssa's out there. I really think...
LUCOR: If you don't pin it, Blondie, I'll chop your tongue out to bung the holes in my sandals. You're going in the hold, for safe-keeping.
GAMMADES: Lucor? Remember a hero's laws. He's my guest and comes with me.
DOCTOR: Thank you, Commander.
GAMMADES: Besides, we need to find the Doctor and this Nyssa. They're your friends, aren't they? They won't go without you. Come.
LUCOR: That's if the Ruhk don't find 'em first.
THOMAS: My Lady? (taps on urn) Lady V, it's me. You still in there? (lid moved) Not at home, then. Still got your jewels, though, so you can't be far.
VUYOKI: Please, help yourself.
THOMAS: Oh, Lady Vuyoki. I'm back, ma'am.
VUYOKI: Oh. Doctor Brewster, it's you.
THOMAS: Didn't think I'd desert you, did ya? I'm the bad farthing, always turning up.
VUYOKI: But it takes such a long time from one always to the next. How much longer must I endure this place?
THOMAS: Did you miss me?
VUYOKI: I've had more attentive callers.
THOMAS: With presents, like the ones I brought ya?
VUYOKI: What have you brought this time?
THOMAS: Well, not so much as it happens. Fact is, I'm stony just now, cleared out, pockets to let.
VUYOKI: You've brought me nothing?
THOMAS: I'll bring you something soon, I swear. You've still got your jewels, though, and the food.
VUYOKI: Oh, it makes the endless days of my after-death bearable. I sit in my bridal urn, chew on a dried bar of porpoise scrapings, and contemplate my next life.
THOMAS: I thought my life was over too. But it ain't, not yet. There's ways back to the world, ma'am.
VUYOKI: There's only one way. We're all dead here, Doctor Brewster. Each condemned to our particular torments. All waiting to be reborn.
THOMAS: What's that? Someone's coming.
VUYOKI: The Ruhk. Help me, Doctor. Secure my lid.
THOMAS: Don't you fret, ma'am, I'm here. I'll soon see him off. I hope.
GAMMADES: Here's my cabin. Find a place where you can.
DOCTOR: Thank you, Commander. Very cosy. Is this a picture of your family?
GAMMADES: My sons. And if I'm not home soon they'll be as old as I am.
DOCTOR: One of the perils of time travel.
GAMMADES: No matter. Let's salute our imminent departure from this rock.
DOCTOR: Ah. I think a celebration may be a bit premature.
GAMMADES: You know, I've nothing against you, Blondie. Not yet. But I don't like the company you keep. Once we find the Doctor we'll open up his Tardis and be away.
DOCTOR: And abandon your magnificent ship? These Calimeran galleys are famous, you know. You were the classical pioneers of trans-temporal voyaging.
GAMMADES: Oh, I don't give up the Gamma lightly. We're heroes, seeking adventure across the ages, returning from the sack of Shermanzi and the Wineskin Cloud. Oh, that was a campaign, I can tell you. I’ve press reports somewhere. I slew the blood-pocked Hippodile of Yoth in hand-to-tooth combat, it was terrific. And when we left, the ship was heavy with booty, but as we slid between the shoals of Time we heard a cry for help.
DOCTOR: Let me guess. A beacon.
GAMMADES: There's always the danger of Sirens. But it might have been some wretched mariner, cast adrift in eternity, so we altered course, following the call, and before we knew it, we were aground, wrecked on this uncharted reef.
DOCTOR: This equipment here. It's a temporal navigation unit. Where exactly did you get it?
GAMMADES: Oh, I traded it with your friend the Doctor. He was here on the reef already touting for business with his Tardis set out like a market stall.
DOCTOR: He sold you stuff from the Tardis?
GAMMADES: Hmm.
DOCTOR: How much did he charge?
GAMMADES: Plenty. Cost us a large chunk of our treasure trove.
DOCTOR: Indeed?
GAMMADES: And I'm damned if any of it works.
DOCTOR: This bit won't. Outside its home it's about as system-compatible as a biscuit in a waterfall. What
DOCTOR: else did he sell you? A fault locator?
GAMMADES: Useless object.
DOCTOR: A food machine?
GAMMADES: Food? Now, that we could have done with. Oh, plenty of other stuff, though. That beacon, the one that lured us here in the first place. He said it might attract rescue.
DOCTOR: Ah.
GAMMADES: And then he saw his chance. Off he went, and we were stranded.
DOCTOR: But it worked. Here we are, except the beacon isn't a beacon.
GAMMADES: What do you mean?
DOCTOR: It's the conceptual geometer from my Tardis. Your so-called beacon is its alarm.
GAMMADES: Your Tardis? It's yours?
DOCTOR: All this equipment is mine, Commander, and I want it back.
GAMMADES: Tough! It was paid for.
DOCTOR: You'll get a full refund and apology. Now, where's the geometer?
GAMMADES: The beacon? It's not here. It's out of reach.
DOCTOR: Commander, I thought my ship was dead, but with the geometer it might still be rescuable.
GAMMADES: (laughs) Oh, that Doctor, eh? He's tricked you too.
DOCTOR: I think this has gone far enough.
GAMMADES: Here, where, where are you off to?
DOCTOR: How big is this reef?
GAMMADES: It's not big, but still growing.
DOCTOR: Then I'm going for a walk. You can come too. The exercise will do you good.
NYSSA: Hello? Anyone there?
THOMAS: Nyssa. it's you.
NYSSA: Brewster.
THOMAS: Keep the door shut.
THOMAS: I'm glad it's you. This place ain't safe. Gives me the jiggers.
NYSSA: I thought you were with the Doctor.
THOMAS: Oh, I was. He sent me to find you.
NYSSA: Then what are you doing in here?
THOMAS: What are you doing with a flock of goats, eh? Got a new job as a shepherdess?
NYSSA: They were showing me the way.
THOMAS: The goats?
NYSSA: I'm looking for the Commander. Do you know him?
THOMAS: No. Why? Who have you been talking to?
NYSSA: Listen, Brewster, it's important. Is this the Commander's ship?
THOMAS: How should I know?
NYSSA: Hmm. Well, it's broken, so it must have crashed. I wonder what all these big jars are for?
THOMAS: I wouldn't touch 'em if I were you.
NYSSA: Oh.
VUYOKI: And who is this?
THOMAS: Er... My Lady Vuyoki. May I introduce...
VUYOKI: Not introduce. How vulgar. Present her to me.
NYSSA: My name is Nyssa of Traken. And you are...?
THOMAS: Nyssa, may I present my Lady Vuyoki.
VUYOKI: I'm far from yours, Doctor Brewster.
NYSSA: Doctor? Oh, this is the lady you told me so much about.
VUYOKI: Did he? What did he say?
THOMAS: Me? I didn't say nothing.
NYSSA: He said how real you were. A real lady.
VUYOKI: Oh.
NYSSA: But he's easily impressed. And all your jewellery. Is that real too? Must be very cramped living in that jar.
VUYOKI: Is this your gift, Brewster? A slave to serve me in my confinement until Old Birth comes to lead me to my new life?
NYSSA: Old Birth? Who's that?
VUYOKI: Quiet. In my old life we fed new slaves on mud so they knew their place. And they didn't speak out of turn.
NYSSA: Brewster, please explain to that lady that I am no servant of hers.
VUYOKI: What?
THOMAS: The truth is, ma'am, Nyssa's not a skiwy. She's a... she's a friend of mine.
VUYOKI: Ah, yes. I could tell. You make such a charming match.
THOMAS: The Ruhk.
NYSSA: It must be following me.
VUYOKI: And you brought it here? You led that misshapen fiend to my inviolable sanctuary? Curse you, you worm. The Ruhk will kill us all.
GAMMADES: When I was newborn, they took me to the Oracle of Calimera. She sat deep in the smoky belly of the world, and foretold my death in glorious battle. My first toy was a sword, and all through school and training, they said I'd be a mighty hero. But I'll never meet my great doom now. At the burning of the Sable Empire, a wounded Sphinx came prowling through the field of dead, the way they do. She found me where I lay bleeding and cursed me to eternal life. Do you think there's a worse fate for a hero? I was trained to die in combat, not live for ever. I'm pinned like an insect between the beating wings of prophecy and curse, and they will tear me apart.
DOCTOR: In my experience, Commander, fortune tellers, even Sphinxes, only ever say half of what they mean. Here, lean on me.
GAMMADES: Thanks. So we were... we were trapped outside Time in a bubble of endless now. The gods, they love to mock us, don't they? But with your Tardis we've hope again.
DOCTOR: I told you, we need the geometer back first.
GAMMADES: You know, we've not sacrificed since the Ruhk stole our goats.
DOCTOR: It stole them? So it's rational, not just a wild beast loose on the reef.
GAMMADES: That's a hundred and thirty days now. I already owe twelve goats on the tally, or their equal. No wonder the gods are cross.
DOCTOR: I don't hold with blood sacrifices. Come on, careful, it’s steep down here.
GAMMADES: My dear chap, how in Deep Heaven do you get anything done?
DOCTOR: I managed, up until now.
GAMMADES: I have dependents.
DOCTOR: Yes. Of course, your sons at home.
GAMMADES: My sons, my crew. And one other. Look. There, see? Between the ridges. That's where she dwells.
DOCTOR: The wreck of a spaceship. How many survivors?
GAMMADES: Just one. A lonely lady, cool as pearl, fiery as the sky. My Lady Vuyoki of Marabou.
DOCTOR: Grand Marabou? How did she get here? Her dynasty rules the stars at the far end of Time to yours.
GAMMADES: She dazzles the reef like a comet with her beauty. I vowed to rescue her from this damnable prison.
DOCTOR: I wish you hadn't done that.
GAMMADES: Come. There's the Doctor's Tardis.
DOCTOR: My Tardis.
GAMMADES: Oh, if you say so. And over the next crest is the Gamma.
DOCTOR: So we've walked for an hour in a straight line right round the circumference of the reef, and we're back where we started.
GAMMADES: The Ruhk. It's hunting again. It's always hunting.
NYSSA: It's just outside.
THOMAS: What are you doing? Nyssa.
NYSSA: I'm going to talk to it.
THOMAS: No.
VUYOKI: You'll speak to that monster?
NYSSA: Why not? It has feelings too.
VUYOKI: Hate, anger.
NYSSA: It can't see. It's lost and confused.
VUYOKI: Oh, poor thing. Yes, perhaps you should go out to it.
THOMAS: No, Nyssa. I won't let you. It ain't safe.
VUYOKI: But she wants to.
THOMAS: No.
VUYOKI: I'm surrounded by heroes.
NYSSA: Brewster, let me go. I promised I'd help the Ruhk.
THOMAS: It knows we're ‘ere.
VUYOKI: It knows she's here. It followed her trail.
THOMAS: Well, it's not going to get her. Come on, ma'am. There must be another way out.
VUYOKI: There is. Through here. This leads to the hold, which has a loading port. From there, just follow the gully upwards. If the rocks haven't overgrown it, it leads towards the Gamma.
NYSSA: The what?
THOMAS: Tell you later. Now, get through there, please.
NYSSA: Oh, very well.
THOMAS: What about you, ma'am?
VUYOKI: I've dealt with the Ruhk before. It won't have forgotten. Now, go.
THOMAS: But ma'am...
VUYOKI: Leave me. Out, out! And don't hurry back. And now for you.
VUYOKI: Hello, monster. Oh, she's gone, your friend. How she laughed at you. Called you a misshapen fiend. You poor thing. But if you hurry you'll soon catch her. I've sent her out the back, to where your nest is. There's no escape for you now, Nyssa of Traken.
GAMMADES: I don't understand. I told Lucor to leave a guard on this Tardis of yours.
DOCTOR: Maybe he didn't want to stand in one place for too long. Look at this. The coral's already growing up the sides.
GAMMADES: One day the reef will fill the whole bubble.
DOCTOR: I don't doubt it.
GAMMADES: Still no sign of the Doctor either. You're his friend, where is he?
DOCTOR: Commander, there's something I should have told you.
GAMMADES: About what?
DOCTOR: About this place, and me. The fact is...
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Hello down there!
GAMMADES: And here he is, right on time.
DOCTOR: Who is that?
GAMMADES: His name was Eumachus. Every galley has apprentice hero.
DOCTOR: A trainee scheme?
GAMMADES: Well, the little fool was trying to get that beacon the Doctor sold us to work.
DOCTOR: I told you, it's not a beacon, it's a conceptual geometer.
GAMMADES: And then the Ruhk attacked, and Eumachus cut his own line, touched the surface of the bubble and got pinned to the sky, poor lad. That's where your geometer thingy is, up there, way out of reach.
DOCTOR: Commander.
GAMMADES: You said you didn't have a key.
DOCTOR: I said only the Doctor has a key, which is true, most of the time. Go on, take a look. This was my Tardis, and my home.
GAMMADES: But... it's dark. It's like a void. It was all space and lights before.
DOCTOR: It's dead, or as good as. It has no dimensional structure, not until I get that geometer back. I'm the Doctor, Commander. Me, not Brewster.
GAMMADES: You?
DOCTOR: Brewster's just a little mudlark with a knack for trouble. He made a fool of me. He stole my Tardis and caused all this inconvenience for you.
EUMACHUS: [OC]: Hello down there!
DOCTOR: This reality bubble we're trapped in, it's generated by the conceptual geometer Brewster sold you. The geometer we can't reach. Time and Space are all churned up here. It takes just one stray polyp of space coral on the Tardis shell, and you've soon got a whole reef to wreck ships and strand innocent lives.
GAMMADES: So... it's your fault?
DOCTOR: That's right. It's my negligence that's trapped us all.
NYSSA: Brewster, stop. This can't be right.
THOMAS: Lady V said to follow the gully.
NYSSA: But it doesn't lead anywhere. It's a dead end.
THOMAS: She said the rocks might have tangled over, and look - one load of tangled-over rocks.
NYSSA: It looks more like a... a nest to me. Brewster, this isn't right, and she knew it wasn't.
NYSSA: Something's coming.
THOMAS: It's only the goats. I expect they followed us.
NYSSA: The Ruhk. I'll speak to it.
THOMAS: No, get down. Hide yourself before we're scrubbed.
RUHK: Quiet, children. I hear you, Nyssa. I smell you. You who betrayed me.
GAMMADES: My Lady Vuyoki, are you there?
VUYOKI: Oh, it's you, Commander. Do you ever take no for an answer?
GAMMADES: But I've brought you something.
VUYOKI: Yes?
GAMMADES: A visitor.
VUYOKI: Oh. Well, it's one caller after another today. You'd best come in.
GAMMADES: Thank you. My Lady, this is the Doctor.
VUYOKI: Another Doctor? Oh!
DOCTOR: Lady Vuyoki, how do you do?
VUYOKI: Is it over? Is my wait over at last.
DOCTOR: Well, I, er...
VUYOKI: Oh, Lords. Spirit forgive me. You may cloak yourself in mortal guise to shield me from your glory, but I Know you. I've spent every solitudinous moment in contemplating my past sins. I'm washed pure of my old life, and ready to be led to my new one.
DOCTOR: Actually, I was looking for two friends of mine.
VUYOKI: But you are he? You must be. He who leads the unborn rejoicing to their new lives. The all-knowing spirit whom we call Old Birth.
DOCTOR: I think you're mistaking me for someone else. About my friends...
VUYOKI: Friends? Oh. You mean that other brat Doctor and his drab little drudge.
DOCTOR: Brewster and Nyssa.
VUYOKI: Oh, I think they passed through. I was at my devotions at the time.
GAMMADES: My Lady, those jewels you're wearing...
VUYOKI: They are mine.
GAMMADES: They were mine first. Booty from a sack of the Sable Empire. How did you come by them?
VUYOKI: They were a gift. People like to give me things. I'm appreciated.
GAMMADES: It was that wretched boy, wasn't it?
DOCTOR: Yes, Brewster's at that sort of age, I'm afraid.
GAMMADES: What else have you got in here?
VUYOKI: Leave that! My bridal urn cannot be defiled.
DOCTOR: Bridal? Looks more like a jar you'd be buried in. These hieroglyphs are very interesting.
VUYOKI: Leave it alone.
DOCTOR: Fascinating. Does this represent your sun?
VUYOKI: I said leave it!
GAMMADES: My Lady.
VUYOKI: What?
GAMMADES: All the dark jewels match your eyes. You are intoxicating.
VUYOKI: Oh!
GAMMADES: No, no, no, don't laugh. My offer of shelter still stands. How can you live alone, no company, no food?
VUYOKI: Oh, go away. Go on, go. And take him with you. I have my prayers to say.
DOCTOR: What about my friends?
VUYOKI: Tedious in the extreme. I dismissed them. They were trying to hide here from the Ruhk.
DOCTOR: You threw them out? Well, where are they now?
RUHK: You are here. But where is here? Children. Where are they?
THOMAS: Don't move. He ain't got eyes.
NYSSA: I promised.
RUHK: Your thoughts betray you, Nyssa of Traken. Here you are!
NYSSA: It's no betrayal. I had no time.
RUHK: Time crushes us all.
THOMAS: Get away from her!
NYSSA: Brewster!
RUHK: The beacon must not sing.
DOCTOR: (approaching) Please, leave my friends alone.
NYSSA: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Nyssa. I'm relieved to see you. Brewster, are you all right?
THOMAS: Fine, just winded.
DOCTOR: Good. And you're the Ruhk, I presume. I'm the Doctor.
NYSSA: It's trapped and alone. It doesn't belong here. In fact, I don't think it belongs in this dimension.
DOCTOR: A para-dimensional being, you mean? That would explain a great deal. Listen, I understand why you're scared. We're all trapped here, but I'll help you if I can.
RUHK: More promises.
DOCTOR: Where do you come from?
RUHK: Not here. An eternal everness of flying free. We never touch the ground.
DOCTOR: I'm sorry. Our dimensions must bind you cruelly.
RUHK: They beguile and crush.
DOCTOR: Trust me. I'll get you away, I give you my word.
GAMMADES: (distant) Get down, all of you, now!
MAN: Come on, lads.
LUCOR: Net away!
GAMMADES: That's got it. Right in the snare. Well done, lads.
DOCTOR: Commander, what are you doing?
LUCOR: Draw it in.
NYSSA: Let it go.
LUCOR: Watch that line. Steady!
GAMMADES: At last. Ha ha, what a prize!
LUCOR: Tighten it up there.
DOCTOR: Let the Ruhk go.
LUCOR: Physter, Thiades, had out the goats. Back to the ship.
DOCTOR: It's a living creature. Set it free now.
GAMMADES: Oh, stop moaning, Doctor. It's all your fault in the first place. Come on now, let's cheer up the old gods with a sacrifice to remember. Back to the ship.
DOCTOR: No, Commander, I won't let that happen.
GAMMADES: Like hell you won't.
NYSSA: Doctor!
THOMAS: Hey!
GAMMADES: And no lip from you two either. Tonight the gods get drunk on blood, and tomorrow we're going home.
LUCOR: Not joining the party, Blondie? Goat meat too strong for ya?
