DOCTOR: I would if I wasn't chained to the mast, Lucor. Call off the sacrifices, the gods don't care about spilt blood.
LUCOR: The gods suit themselves, as long as I don't lose my ship.
DOCTOR: You won't. Only fools lose their ships. Let the Ruhk go. Let's get the beacon back.
LUCOR: Not a chance. The lad's got it. Eumachus, up on the surface, out of reach.
DOCTOR: What about your harpoon?
LUCOR: What? This little beauty. No. I ain't gonna skewer him.
DOCTOR: You could attach a net, like the one you used on the Ruhk.
LUCOR: I tried that already. It didn't stick. Let him float in peace, poor lad. Round and round. At least he never stops laughing.
DOCTOR: Of course. Sorry to bother you, enjoy your party. Brewster, did you get it?
THOMAS: Easy. He's too soused to notice a dipper. Here. One key for the harpoon, and one for your chains. Hold still.
DOCTOR: Thank you. Now, let's prime the harpoon. Insert the key.
THOMAS: Like this?
DOCTOR: Perfect. Good. It's auto-loading. Set to stun, I think. That should knock the geometer out of Eumachus's grasp. Now, where's our orbiting apprentice gone?
NYSSA: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Not now, Nyssa.
NYSSA: What's happening? You're not trying to get the geometer back?
DOCTOR: And solve everything in one giant leap. Yes, I'm afraid so, it's an unfortunate habit I have.
NYSSA: But the Ruhk begged us not to activate the alarm.
THOMAS: There he is.
EUMACHUS: [OC}: Hello down there!
NYSSA: No. It pleaded. There'll be more trouble.
LUCOR: Hoi. What's all the fuss?
DOCTOR: The whole reef may collapse, but if we can get the geometer back inside the Tardis ... Ah. Got him right in my sights.
LUCOR: Commander. The Doctor. He's loose!
GAMMADES: What?
NYSSA: Doctor, no.
DOCTOR: Sorry, Nyssa. (harpoon fired) Oh. Missed. So close.
GAMMADES: What are you playing at, disturbing the boy.
NYSSA: The beacon.
DOCTOR: The bolt must have reactivated it.
THOMAS: Look at the sky. There's a storm coming.
GAMMADES: Batten the forceshields. Storm warning.
LUCOR: Aye, aye, Commander.
NYSSA: Ruhks.
THOMAS: Hundreds of 'em.
LUCOR: Monsters ahoy!
GAMMADES: We'll be over-run.
DOCTOR: The whole Ruhkery, falling from the sky like rain. They're beaching.
GAMMADES: You idiot, you've led them here, and now they're going to kill us all.

elements.text: [Part Three]
All crew maintain defence positions, ready to repel boarders.
They're surrounding the ship.
Dirty, crawling things. What do they want?
They're blind, Commander, and in pain.
They're drawn to the geometer like moths to a flame. Our dimensions are too heavy. They'd crumple up like umbrellas in a gale.
And they want their friend back.
Easy targets, Commander. We can pick 'em off with the harpoon, one by slithering one.
No!
Who's giving the orders round here? Proceed, Captain.
Nyssa's right, Gammades. The blast will destabilise the reef.
The Ruhks are innocent.
Course they are, Miss. About as innocent as your two Doctors.
Look at the Ruhks. What are they doing?
Something's scared them. Opening up like the Red Sea.
[OC]: Old Birth! Old Birth, I come to you.
Blimey, it's her. It's Vuyoki.
Lucor, open the doors.
She's walking straight through them.
Are you crazy?
Open the doors. It's my Lady. She's coming to us. Oh, she is fearless.
They're terrified, more like. They can't get out of her way fast enough.
I must welcome her aboard.
Rapping on door.
[OC]: Open up! The Lady Vuyoki demands it.
Captain Lucor, don't open those doors.
You think it's a trap?
What would she want with the likes of us? We're way below her.
Everybody's below her.
She talked to me.
Only because she thought you were me. Keep them shut, Lucor.
[OC]: Lucor, it's Gammades. Get these damn doors open.
No! Talk to her first. Why’s she here?
[OC]: Lucor!
Sorry, Doctor. You don't have to live with him. (loud) Disengaging locks, Commander.
[OC]: About time too.
Nyssa, Brewster, go down to the hold and try to free the Ruhk.
What about you?
I have my respects to pay.
My Lady, come inside away from the Ruhks. Hurry, my Lady. We're under siege.
Is he here?
You mean the Ruhk we caught?
Why would I care about the Ruhk? I meant him. Old Birth himself.
They're moving. Please, come in now.
He cloaks his immortal shape, but I know it's a test.
Commander, I really don't think it's wise.
Ah! I knew he was here. Now I shall enter.
At last. Lucor, close the doors.
Doors close.
Welcome aboard the Gamma, my Lady. It took such courage to reach us. My own cabin is yours. Er, my crew will of course endeavour to ensure your Ss...
Somebody bring my bags.
Rumble.
It's a tremor. Hold tight, all of you!
Sounds like the whole reef's breaking up.
Not yet. But the dimensional bubble can't be sustained for ever, and if the coral goes on growing... Why are you staring?
Old Spirit. I have found you again.
Not so much of the old, thank you. Look, I don't know who you think I am but...
It was the final trial, wasn't it? To seek you out, the Messenger of Birth. I have renounced my home and walked through the forces of darkness to reach you.
To reach him?
Old one, I am ready to be led to my new life.
That's as maybe, but I'm not your Messenger of Birth, and as far as I can see you are still very much alive.
No. No, I'm not.
Please. Talk to your host. He's alive too. Despite the siege and the tremors, he's champing at the bit to talk to you. I have better things to do.
That's funny. There's no one on guard down here.
Suppose they're all on deck. I meant, for the battle.
There must be a light. Ah. (click) Urgh. Urgh.
Blimey.
Oh!
It's a proper charnel-house. Like one of ‘em Penny Blood's ain't it? String Of Pearls, Mother's favourite bedtime story.
So that's what became of the goats. All sacrificed to the gods. These people are meant to be civilised.
Distant cawing.
What's that?
Let's just - move - some of these billies aside. Here he is, all trussed up like a Christmas goose. Looks like the Commander's going to make a big show of him.
We must cut him down. Help me, Brewster.
All right. Oh, these nets are spun metal. We'll never cut through ‘em.
So, this world ends.
We'll get you out of here. Don't worry.
Tell the Doctor Time, measured in the beating of so many hearts, lies spilling on the floor.
Well, Lucor, what news?
The Ruhks are moving, sir, crawling closer.
Look at them. A hundred more victims lining up for sacrifice.
Your world keeps shrinking, doesn't it, Commander?
Save us, that Doctor again.
Soon it'll be a sea of blood and the gods still won't be impressed. Don't mind me.
Any moment now those Ruhks will surge over my ship, so let's have one decent battle to finish this for good.
Can't be soon enough.
Come on, come on.
What are you doing, man?
I'm collecting items from my dead Tardis.
If it gives you comfort.

The fault locator was in the hold. Bit scratched, but never mind. And under here, if I can just... (effort) Yeah! Ah, gotcha. Yes, that's the power lens unit. Of course, we already know about the inaccessibility of my conceptual geometer.
Deep gods. Save us from the pedant.
Mister Plester, did you ask my Lady to join us for one last meal?
She refused, sir. Says she has food of her own.
Does she indeed? That might explain what happened to the food machine.
Commander, the Ruhks. They've gone quiet again.
Brewster, hurry up. I think the ship's starting to move.
Shh. Someone's crying, in ‘ere.
Door opens.
Get out. Leave me alone.
Vuyoki.
Lady V, what's the matter? Who's upset you?
That man. That Doctor. He says I'm not dead. But I am.
Where's that Doctor gone?

Never mind him, Lucor. Remember men, all of you, every death is an offering. You or them. And every stand may be your last, so make it count. You're the best crew a hero could have. Fifty goldoons to the man who sacrifices the most.
Roosters on the prow.
This is it. Men, we're at war. Lower the forceshields, Captain. Let them in!
It's started. A real life battle.
Don't you want to know how I died?
Yes. Yes, we do. Please go on.

Each year, at the dead of harvest, a tribute flies in thanks to Marabou, our Sun, may he never go dark. I was his chosen bride, packed in my bridal urn on a ceremonial starship with fifty jars of grain.
You mean you were the sacrifice?
No better than the Commander's goats.

I missed the festivities held in my honour. They'd put me in my jar by then. And then the ship blasted off to my marriage. But it never happened. There was some sort of storm and... I crashed here. Dead among the dead people.
I'm sorry for your suffering.

Beset by torment and monsters. Waiting most devoutly for the messenger of Birth to lead me from the after-death to my next life. And in all that time, the only one to show me kindliness was this beardless boy.
Me?
You, with your blessed food machine. How could I live in a dead way without you?
How very generous.
Doctor?
I underestimated your compassionate streak, Brewster. How much did you charge her?
I didn't. I gave her the food machine. She needed help.
And the jewels? Your profit on my sold-off property? No doubt she needed them as well.
I did, yes.
Harpoons. Gammades is a fool. He'll never defeat the Ruhk that way.
Doctor, we can't stay here.
True. Anyway, Brewster, what about Nyssa? Maybe she'd have liked some jewellery too.
Actually, I'm...
But we weren't there, were we? You'd hopped the twig, hadn't you? You were obviously selling off bits of my Tardis at your local car boot sale.
I know, all right? My fault, but leave the Lady alone, right? She's not to blame.
Are you sure of that?
Yes, I am.
Good. Good, that's better. Well, now we've cleared the air we'd better save the Ruhk.
Before both sides wipe each other out.
Exactly. Come on!
Mai‘am,, I...
Go on. Go yapping after your master.
He's not my master.
Then stay. I'm sure I'll think of some tasks for you.
(laughs) That's not a bad battle. I'd almost forgotten the smell of the fight.
It's been far too long. Look out!
2: Our brother, where is he?
Out of your reach. His neck's bared for the knife.
2: Set him free!
They’re pulling back. Cowards!
It's a rout. Put up the forceshields, Lucor, we need a break.
Steady. We're moving.
The whole reef's cracking round us. We can try and pull free.
Engine room. Mister Phyton. Get the furnaces up to full burn, now.
[OC]: (Scots) Aye, aye, Captain.
How's that, Ma'am?
Oh, good, Brewster. Oh, you have a way with feet.
Well, you've got to take care of your plates.
Oh/1
Oh, sorry, did I er...
There, at the porthole! (glass breaks) Marabou protect me!
Get out of here! Get out! Go on, get out!
Stand aside, boy. Never leave the windows unshuttered.
Sorry, I didn't realise.
It's dead, my Lady.
The darkness pursues me.
Just a Ruhk.
A monster.
But you walked through ranks of them before.
So brave you were.
Oh, even in my death the darkness follows.
Death? What are you saying, you silly woman? You're not dead.
Yes I am.

No, you have a heart, don't you? What's that beating so fast in your breast, eh? You see? There now. I'll protect you, my Lady. And soon, gods willing, we'll be away from here. You don't need a messenger of birth. Oh no. I'm where your new life begins.
My hero.
Ahem. I'll just, er... I'll go and find the Doctor.
It's all right, my friend. We'll get you out of here. You'd need a diamond laser to cut through these nets, and somehow I don't see Commander Gammades lending us one.
I don't know. He might surprise you. My people saw goodness in everything.
Most edifying.
It just needs tending and bringing on like a seedling.
Even Lady Vuyoki?
I like a challenge.
Oh, where's Brewster? He's good at opening things.
We fear Vuyoki. Her heart pure with dark. Touch her never.
Well, sometimes even I find being reasonable a bit wearisome.
Surely not? The control lines go up through the ceiling. On deck, probably.
What happens when you're free?
Ah. Then we fly unbound, turning high in the radiance, back to the everness beyond choking passages of Time. Up, down, far, near. Thoughts are colours thriving in the endless air.
Pan-dimensional places I'll never go to, I'm afraid.
Door opens.
How can you stay in this butcher's shop?
Ah, Brewster, there you are at last. Any thoughts on this mesh...?
Those are power cells engaging. They must be trying the engines.
Idiots. They'll tear the reef apart.
Brewster, mind the door, it's not got a handle on...
Door closes.
This side.
Sorry.
We're trapped.
It comes again.
Another tremor. Hold on.
More power, Mister Phyton. Shake 'em off the hull.
Not enough grade, Captain. We should power down.
Keep it going.
We'll tear apart.
That's it. We'll never break free.
Never thought I'd hear you surrender, Lucor.
Come on.
Where's the hero who sliced through the mob of Gug-truckers at Gagoor and split their five- eyed King in three?
I'm an old campaigner. Sometimes I want my home and pension.
Rubbish! You'll outlast me. Phyton, how long before we try again?
Give it ten beats, Commander. I need to patch this up first.
Right. Lucor, order all hands above. And bring up our pet Ruhk. Let's give the gods what they want. A sacrifice.
1: Claw a way in. Save our brother from the dark.
2: There is no way. We've come too far. The end approaches.
1: The end looms, Abadin. Above us all.
2: It poises to strike.
1: Oh. No!
2: No!
1: No!
2: No!
1: The sky is crashing in. Rescuing.
2: Sky and ground will meet. They'll crush us all!
1: No escape from above.
2: No escape.
1: No escape.
1 + RUHK 2: Above! Above! Above!
No good. The door's jammed good and proper.
There must be another way out.
If the ship breaks free, we'll never reach the Tardis again.
What's the point? You said the Tardis was dead.
It is.
Unless we reach the geometer.
So it isn't?
Above.
Above? Yes?
Above.
The hatchway up there. We'll never reach it.
It will come to us.
What's happening?
The hatch is coming down.
No. The floor's going up.
The hatch, it's opening.
And up he rises. Impressive, is it not, my Lady?
Is this the ceremony?
At present the formal embellishments of a ritual are beyond us. We have to make do.
I'm sure your gods will understand.
They're your gods now too.
What fun.
Commander!
Oh, it's him.
Walking towards them.
Doctor, the sky, it's coming closer.
The dimensional field must be at its limit. The geometer can't sustain it much longer.
And then the reef collapses?
Oh, can't those Ruhks out there be quiet? They make my head pound. Quiet, quiet!
Lightning.
Stand back, Doctor. We've a sacrifice to make.
The Ruhk's done you no harm.
It steals. It killed one of my crew.
Accidents, I'm sure. It's lost and confused.
The gods demand a sacrifice.

But a true sacrifice means giving up something you depend on, not the murder of a bystander. Here. This is the energy lens from my Tardis. It'll focus the power in your neutron engines. That should get your ship away.
It never worked before.
Did you even know what it was? Fitted at a resonance level of eight thousand cycles it's auto- compatible.
Hmm. Lucor?
It could work, Commander. Maybe.
Then take it, on trust.
Right.
Doctor, don't you need that for the Tardis?
What's more important, my ship or the Ruhk? Commander, please release him now.
The gods still need an offering.
How should I know? I'm just telling you what he told me. He said to fit it at a resonance level of eight thousand cycles.
And this bitty thing'll do the trick?
Just try it, Phyton. What do we have left to lose?
Power starts up.
Blimey. That was quick.
Let the Ruhk go, Commander, please.
I've sworn to lead my Lady Vuyoki here to a new life. The sacrifice will bless our union.
Our destinies are entwined.
My sons need a new mother, Doctor.
Not her, surely? Can't you read? Didn't you see the inscription on her funeral urn?
Bridal urn. Pay no attention, my love.
Weren't they hieroglyphs?
Oh yes. Roughly translated, they read Marabou, Great Star...
Be silent!
Take into your fiery heart this lost soul by whose murderous hand two thousand slaves met their deaths. Cleanse her of the wickedness for which we on this world have no remedy.
But... I mean, she said she was the bride of the Sun.
She lied, Thomas.
Of course I lied. They were laughing at me, those giggling hyenas. I tripped and fell on the palace steps, and how they all laughed. But I made them pay.
There, there, my love. They were only slaves.
Aren't you all?
How you two deserve each other. Time we were going.
Permit me to offer you free passage.
Stay with you? I'd rather go back to my dead Tardis. But before I do, let the Ruhk go.
Don't blame me, it's the gods who want the sacrifice. And when it's done, we're going home. There's nothing else to keep us here.
Hello down there.
Oh, the dead boy. How he returns to haunt us.
And still clutching my geometer.
Oi, Doctor, how does this thing work?
Hand me that controller, you thief. At once.
Sorry, mate. If you ain't gonna release the Ruhk, then I am.
Oh no you don't.
Commander, leave him alone!
Crush him, my love. Break the boy.
Nyssa, catch.
Got it! Logically, this must be the sequence. Epsilon, Gamma, Alpha, Alpha, Omega.
Don't touch that!
Ruhk freed.
Well done, Nyssa. Brewster, are you all right?
Never better. Thanks, Doctor.
So, it's a fight you want, is it monster? Well, why not? Sword to beak. Back to the gory glory days of youth. For you, my Lady.
Fly, Doctor, back to your home. Fly away.
Calimera!
That's the gangplank. Brewster, Nyssa, time to jump ship!
All hands, prepare for launch.
The engines.
The ship's moving.
Onto the gangplank, quickly.
Doctor, we can't go down there. The reef's in meltdown.
We must, before the ship goes. Now, jump!
Hang onto me, both of you.
Which way? The dimensions are shifting so much it's hard to focus.
Don't worry, I can see. Look out.
2: Take your flight.
What's that? It's... beautiful.
It's a Ruhk. Freed up into its true pan-dimensional form. Dazzling, isn't it?
I saw a kingfisher once, out on Deptford Creek. That was a titch next to this.
2: Stop wasting time. Are you ready?
Yes. Ready when you argh!
Doctor!
Bring him back!
1: Do not worry. He has something to find.
The geometer. Is he fetching that?
1: And you too are going home.
What a view. The whole reef's dissolving. The Gamma's broken free. It's leaving.
Hello down there!
2: Take the instrument.
Sorry, Eumachus, old chap. Time to give up your birthday. I can't quite...
2: Take it!
Ah! Got it. Right, home we go.
Hello down there!
Here is your machine. Farewell.
Wait! What about...?
Great. No Doctor, and we sit outside the Tardis like a brace of bloaters in a snowstorm.
Oh! Come on, Doctor, where are you?
There. He's flying in. Oi, Doctor!
Ah. Thank you. Thank you very much.
1: Just be more thoughtful next time.
Nyssa, Brewster, let's get this geometer installed, shall we?
But there's nothing inside, just nothing.

Look more carefully. There, you see? About ten feet away, that tiny grey cluster is all the Tardis dimensions crushed into a singular knot. Now, somehow we have to link this geometer to that knot so it can unravel the dimensions.
Yes, but how? We can't even reach it.
What you need's a pole, or a boat-hook.
Yes, that might work.
Except we ain't got one.
No.
The reef's breaking up.
Give me that thing. I'll do it.
No Brewster, you can't just jump in there, you'll be annihilated.
Well, someone's got to do something.
Thomas, don't!
Be seeing ya!
No!
He's gone.
Thomas Brewster. Another wasteful sacrifice.
Wait. The Tardis - it's unravelling. Opening like a flower.

You're right. Spatial dimensions extrapolated and initiated. Temporal drivers installed, astral navigator installed, memory banks retrieved! Power systems activated. Internal architectural reinstated. Yeah. A bit more to the left, perhaps? Perfect. He did it. Brewster did it.
My Tardis. Restored.
Tardis door closes.
Yes, but at what cost?
Chime.
Nyssa.
Ruhk. You escaped from Gammades.
The Commander's blade could not harm me once the dimensions coalesced.
I'm glad. Glad something survived.
The Commander's ship is safe also. And I found this, lost in the void.
Chime.
Brewster.
Doctor. Nyssa.
Brewster, you're all right. Thank you, Ruhk. I'm most grateful.
Please take better care of him in future.
Chime.
Oh yes. I certainly will.
He meant me, Brewster. Anyway, I'm glad you're back. I can always build another food machine.
And the energy lens? Can we still travel without that?
Ah, yes, that is a problem.
I don't know what you're on about. There's a whole boxful of them in a downstairs cupboard.
There are? You mean, you didn't give away the only one?
No, no, of course not. Whatever made you think I'd do that? Now, Brewster, if you wouldn't mind fetching me one of the lenses, er, we can be on our way.
Of course, Doctor. Anything you say.
And the Gamma?
Well away by now, Gammades and Vuyoki. I'm sure we wish them every joy and many long years of wedded bliss.
Four degrees star-ward, Mister Plester.
Four degrees it is, sir.
Cheer up, my love. We'll soon be home.
The stars blaze for me. A new life at last.
A fresh start, and you'll soon settle down to army life. Of course, the barracks are a bit basic.
Basic?
But my sons will be thrilled to meet their new mother.
Mother?
Here, lads. Five cheers for my new bride.
Huzzah! Huzzah! Huzzah! Huzzah! Huzzah!
Oh. I can hardly contain my excitement, my love.
A Perfect World, by Jonathan Morris
A Big Finish Productions Dr Who Audio Drama, released Sep 2008
TV on in the background.
Taz, you could at least pick up the post.
Sorry. It's all you, though. Bills mainly.
Thanks. You want a cup of tea?
No milk.
You could have got some in. What have you done all day?
Don't take it out on me.
I'm not, it's just... oh, I've had the day from hell. They're closing my department, the Jubilee Line was like Dawn of the Dead, and I thought my flatmate, while she was out looking for a job...
I'm sorry, I forgot, all right?
What are you watching anyway?
News. There's a diet thing on later on Five I thought I might watch. Just in case I felt like going on a diet.

Good evening. Here is the News at six o'clock. The Health Minister today resigned following the leaked correspondence regarding the outbreak of hospital-acquired infections. In other news, flooding in Pakistan has left thousands homeless without clean drinking water.
Stylophone-Knees rang. Something about missing rent?
Brilliant. Anything else?
I don't know. I put the phone on answer. I was having a bath. Oh, that reminds me. You need to get a plumber bloke in. Er, the little light isn't coming on?
You have two new messages.
Could you turn that down for a sec? Taz? Volume?
Sorry. Excuse me for not being totally perfect.
[answerphone]: Hello, Connie, this is your mother. I'm just calling to say, if you need me, use my mobile, because your father and I have had another argument.
[answerphone]: Hi, babes. Richie speaking. Look, I know I was going to see you tonight, but ... Kick it! Well, the thing is, we're not really going anywhere, so er we should probably...
Taz, I'm going out.
Wa-wa-watch out...
Tyres squeal.
Oi! You blind or something?
Sorry, sorry.
What the hell was she playing at, eh?
You know, just once, it would be nice if something in my life didn't turn out total rubbish.
You all right?
I'm sorry. I don't have any cash on me.
Not after your money.
Look, no offence, but I'd rather be alone right now.
Fine, it's just, well, this is Southwark Bridge. What with you looking down at the river...
I'm not going to jump, if that's what you think.
My mistake.
What are you, a Samaritan looking for business?
Me? No, no, no, I'm... I'm no one.
No one?
I used to live round ‘ere - work, you know, bit further down, past London Bridge. On the banks. Mudlarking for Mister Creek. Whole gang of us.
Really? And did you consider yourself at home?
Ages ago now, though. Weren't like all this, all lit up and pretty. The river was like a whole city of ships thick with smoke and noise, and... and...
What? What were you going to say?
Nothing, but... now it's all so clean, the air.
(You call this clean?
Well, there's no fog or nothing. No horses, and... you don't smell hardly at all.
(Thanks.
Can see why you come 'ere. It's beautiful.
And really freezing.
Yeah. I didn't want to mention it, but it ain't half nipping.
This is probably a mad mistake but, I know this place that does coffee, late night, if you're interested?
Yeah. Why not? I like coffee.
Okay, that's fine, yeah.
And that's why you went for a walk?
It might not be much in the grand scheme of things, but yeah. I mean, the way the world's going...
The world?
Don't you watch the news’? It's all about some war that shouldn't have happened or a famine that could have been avoided, or the polar ice caps melting.
Which is bad, right?
Yeah, it confuses the penguins. I just can't help feeling things are getting worse.
Say you were someone from a hundred years ago. What would you think then?
Someone like you, you mean?

Yeah, I mean you'd think you was in Paradise. Everyone's healthy, so much food you don't know what to eat first. You got machines that take you anywhere you want to go, and... you got these. What are these called again?
Caramel macchiatos.
Yeah. You know what the best thing is? Men have stopped going around with big bushy beards.
Look, you're right, but it doesn't make facing tomorrow any easier.
Yeah. It's something to look forward to, ain't it?
It's good talking to you. I was wrong about the being alone.
Well, I like listening, to you.
Richie doesn't do listening. Doesn't do really anything that's not all about him.
Richie your, er...?
Boyfriend.
Oh.
Ex. But don't get your hopes up. I bought you coffee. Count yourself lucky you got that much.
I will.
Drink up.
So where are you from, anyway?
I told you. London, the Spike. The workhouse.
No, but really.
Really.
Your face. You actually believe you're from...
1867, yeah.
Right. And you're here, how?
You won't laugh if I tell ya?
No, I think I probably will.
See that blue hut, by the road?
Police Public Call Box.
I sort of go through Time in it. Travel to other worlds.
You go to other worlds?
Yeah, I've seen... You won't believe me, but I've seen 2008. A different one where things went wrong.
I get it. I should be happy 'cos I live in a perfect world.
Well, not perfect. I mean, who'd want to live in a perfect world?
I would. I think it'd make a nice change. Look, I'll er, see you around, okay?
When? How will I find you?
Hang on. For when you next come down to Earth, my mobile.
Your what?
You haven't got a mobile?
No.
Right. I'm 6 A Shad Row, but if you turn out to be a stalker, I'll introduce you to my flatmate, and I should warn ya, she's built like a brick privy.
Six A. Got ya.
Well, bye. Nice meeting ya.
You too.
Hang on. I don't even know your name.
Thomas Brewster.
Nice meeting you, Thomas Brewster. Connie Winter.
Right.
Tardis door opens.
You're not seriously thinking of getting in that thing, are you?
Tardis door closes. The Tardis dematerialises.
Oh - my - God.
Black Country accents.
You heard the girl, Trev, it's a call-out. Emergency Code Nine.
It's not a call-out.
It's a Code Nine. We don't have any choice. That's how it works. Regulations.
All right, Phil. If you say so.
The Tardis materialises.
Earth, London, 2008, as requested. You know, sometimes I feel as though I'm running a glorified taxi service.
As requested?
Brewster. Wanted to know what the future should be like. All he saw of 2008 was...
A smouldering desolation.
Yes. Give him a call, could you?
Thomas? We've landed.
Now, where are we exactly? Hello. That looks rather familiar.
Your old study, in your house on Baker Street.
Yes. This dust hasn't been disturbed for over a century. I must have forgotten to pay the cleaner.
The furniture is falling to pieces. It's only the cobwebs holding them together.
Nonsense, Nyssa. They were new when I bought them and now they're... genuine antiques. With a spot of woodworm, admittedly.
So this is the year 2008.
Well, yes, but you're not seeing the best of it. Help me with this. You're handy with windows. There. Now, look.
It's like - nothing I've ever seen before. Carriages without horses.
Doctor, do you mean to say that this house has lain empty for 141 years?
I gave my solicitor strict instructions it shouldn't be sold on or let. I've grown quite attached to the old place. Still have the title deeds somewhere. Come on, time for some fresh air.
It certainly looks different from the last time we were here.
What do you think, Brewster? Impressive, isn't it?
Yeah, yeah. Right, so, er if this is Baker Street then the underground station's that way?
Yes, on the left.
In that case. I'm sorry, Doctor, Miss Nyssa, I've got to dash.
What?
Catch you later. Someone I have to see.
That boy!
Doctor, I don't understand.
I think I do. Brewster. He's been here before.
Alarm beeps, knock on door.
Oh, what? Oh, God.
Connie?
Yes? Yeah, come in.
Door opens.
My turn to make you your early morning cup of tea.
Who are you, and what have you done with my flatmate? Sorry, I... weren't we out of milk?
No. I saw you were running low, so I picked some up on the way home from work yesterday.
From work? You have a job?
Yes.
Doing what, may I ask?
Management consultancy. I didn't spend three years at University to sit around all day.
You didn't spend three years at University.
Draw the curtains, shall I?
Oh my... Taz!
I'd rather you called me Tasmin. What is it?
It's just... you're so slim.
Thanks. I do my best. Though all credit to my personal trainer.
Okay, now this has to be a dream. I'm staying in bed till it goes away.
What, lie in? Not like you. Still, you were out late last night.
Yes.
How was Richard? Oh, I do like him. I think you're perfect together.
We split up.
I don't think so. Remember your good news?
My what?
You told me last night. Richard proposed. It's odd you don't remember.
So this isn't the first time Thomas has visited this century.
No. Oh, I should have guessed. He asked to be brought here. Even specified the exact date.
And you didn't think that suspicious?
When he saw the traffic he should have been amazed, bewildered, terrified. He accepted it all much too easily.
Because he'd seen it all before.
Yes, he must have come here when he was on his own, travelling in my Tardis.
So where do you think he's gone?
Hmm. Strange.
Doctor?
Nyssa, this may sound odd, but have you noticed, this is the early morning rush hour.
So?
So the traffic should be at a virtual standstill. But it's moving. Everyone's moving.
Is that all?
No, no, no. Something's wrong here. I can feel it.
Have you tidied the bathroom?
Not particularly, why?
It looks like a hotel in there. I just want to check something. Where do I work?
Rothery House?
Right. Still the same, not going bonkers. Hang on. The machine.
Beep.
You have one new message.
[answerphone]: Hello, Connie. This is your mother. I'm just calling about this weekend, only your father has surprised me by booking a mini-break to Penrith, near where we had...
I don't believe it.
Believe what?
Wait.

Good morning. Here is the news. The Health Minister today announced the eradication of all hospital-acquired infections. In other news, flooding in Pakistan has been avoided following a new internat...
The news, it's changed, everything. Taz...
Tasmin.
Tasmin. Did you take a message yesterday from Stylophone-Knees?
You mean Mister Stylianides?
Yes.
No. Why, is there something wrong?
No, no, quite the opposite. Look, I'll see you later.
Times! Inflation falls!
A copy of The Times, please.
Cheers, mate.
Doctor, what are you looking for?
Today's news stories. Anything strike you as odd?
Ah. Palestinian peace accord, inflation falls, schools achieve record exam results. It all seems normal.
Where are the political scandals, the disasters, the binge-drinking celebrities all over the front page. Can't you see? It's all good news.
Good news?
And as for the sports pages. Graham Swann, a hundred not out?
Doctor...
It's been in front of our noses all along. The people, Nyssa, the people.
They all seem perfectly happy.
Precisely, and healthy. Every one of them. No, this isn't the Earth, not as we know it. Something
has changed humanity, for the better.
What? That's ridiculous.
Is it? It's as if the whole world has been... well, improved.
Maybe it's the result of a shift in history. Doctor, what if Thomas did something, when he was travelling in the Tardis?
No, an alteration in the time stream wouldn't have such universally benign consequences. But you're right about one thing. Whatever's happening, Thomas Brewster is at the heart of it.
Shad Row Flats, 6 A. Come on. (knocks on door) Come on, come on.
Door opens.
2: Hello, yes?
Glad I caught ya. Thought you might be out.
2: Well, you're lucky, I was just leaving. What can I do for you?
It's me from last night.
2: Last night.
On the bridge. Thomas. I've come back. I wanted to see ya.
2: I'm afraid I don't have a clue what you're talking about.
Come on, girl.
2: Don't talk to me like that. I don't know you. And looking at you, I don't want to know you.
Closing her door over.
Connie.
2: Excuse me. I have a job to go to.
We had a coffee, you and me.
2: That never happened. I'm sorry.
Wait. You said you and your boyfriend Richie had split up.
2: Richard and I are very happy together - in fact, we're engaged. Not that it has anything to do with you. Now, I have to go.
Okay, they've tidied up. Unlikely, but could happen.
Hello, Rothery House Publishing? No problem.
Sophie?
Oh, Connie. Good morning.
You would not believe my journey to work today.
No?
Every train was on time, and I got a seat.
That's not unusual.
What's happened here? Half the people are different and the ones that aren't the same aren't the same, and... you're working.
I'm working?
I don't mind, but usually you spend the first half of the morning reading celebrity magazines while scoffing a box of éclairs.
Oh, you are funny, Connie.
You think I'm joking?
Celebrity magazines? I'm still working my way through The Brothers Karamazov as well you know. And I don't eat éclairs unless they form part of a healthy balanced diet.
Okay, freaking me out now. Hang on, this is my desk.
It's not your desk. Well, it is your desk, I suppose, of course, but you don't work here, do you?
Oh, right, I see.
I mean, you have your own office.
My own office?
It would be a bit odd for you not to have your own office when you run the whole company.
Chop-chop. Back to the Tardis.
We're not leaving, are we?
No, but if there has been some extra-terrestrial interference, we might be able to locate the source, or find... Brewster.
What?
Doctor, Nyssa. You're still here.
Where have you been?
You've visited this time before.
I'll tell you everything you want to know, but I've got to tell you something first. Something you're not going to believe.
Miss Winter? Someone to see you.
You all right? You look like you've... Oh my God.
Miss Winter ... Miss Winter.
2: Who are you, and what are you doing in my office?
You? You're ... You're me.
2: What?
I don't believe it. Even my clothes look better on you.
2: You haven't answered my question.
Don't you get it? I'm you. But you shouldn't be here.
2: I think perhaps it is you who should not be here.
No, you're making a mistake.
2: A mistake? I don't make mistakes.
What?
2: I've never made a mistake in my life.
You mean you're... When you were sixteen years old, Nathan Green's birthday party, what did you do?
2: I don't see how...
I got drunk and snogged Sean Clarke's brother. Did you do that?
2: No. I don't like to drink alcohol, except in moderation.
French A Level. I got so nervous, I throw up over the invigilator.
2:1 got an A.
Kaiser Chiefs concert, 2004, I went to the wrong Newcastle.
2: How could anyone go to the wrong Newcastle? You think I'm...?
Yeah. You're a version of me that never got anything wrong, never messed up. You're perfect. All of you. Everybody, except for me.
2: Well, yes. We are perfect.
Everyone's perfect.
2: What could be wrong with that?
I've got to go. You're all... pod people from the planet Knitwear. Well, you're not getting me.
So this girl you met...
Connie. A real doxy, she was.
Had been substituted.
What's that?
Changed.
Yeah, that's it. But the new girl was sort of different-looking. Like, glowing, but unfriendly, full of herself.
Last time you were here, what did you do, who did you speak to?
Just Connie. No one else. It's not my fault.
Not deliberately, but... Well, that shouldn't be happening. Oh no. Oh no!
Doctor?
Brewster, you didn't materialise the Tardis properly, did you?
What?
You created a quantum fissure in the fabric of Space-Time. This girl you met must be the focal nexus. We have to find her before it's too late.
I told you, she's gone.
No, no, no. If she's part of what's causing this, there should still be a real Connie out there.
The real Connie, the one I met on the bridge? She's still around?
We need to locate her before the wave function collapses. Brewster, any ideas?
I've tried her flat. She weren't there. Not the real her. She must have gone out.
Anywhere else you can think she might be? Or do you want the world to be stuck like this for ever?
Southwark Bridge.
Where I met her. There she is. Connie, oi!
Thomas.
It's you. You recognise me.
Well, of course I do, I only met you last night. And who are your...?
We're friends of Brewster's. I'm Nyssa.
And I'm the Doctor.
Right, and you're on your way to a fancy dress party. Let me guess. Bertie Wooster, right?
Bertie Wooster?
We're here because something has been affecting your planet. You may not have noticed, but...
Of course I've noticed. It's not every day the whole world turns into a Richard Curtis movie. And on top of that, I met myself at work today.
You did what?
Except - and this was the scary part - she was better looking than me, and she had this really great career and had never done anything wrong, she was...
Perfect.
Yeah, but also really annoying.
What does Connie have to do with this? If it was my...
Because whatever is doing this, it's doing it for her.
What?
We need your help. If you could join us in the...
Oh my God, the blue box.
You've seen it before?
Yeah, last night.
After you, Miss Connie.
Whoa! This thing, it's bigger on the inside.
Yes, you're not the first to have noticed.
What is all this? A mobile disco?
It's my machine for going through Time.
Your machine?
Doctor...
Well, all right. It sort of belongs to the Doctor.
Er, never mind that now, Miss, er...
Winter.
If you could just stand there, we need to establish the source of the quantum disruption.
Doctor...
Yes, a fissure on the fabric of Space-Time, it... Odd. Something seems to have broken through. Two life-forms?
Doctor...
Doctor, look.
What?
Clatter of tool bag dropping.
Who are you, and what are you doing in my Tardis?
Who are we? We had a call-out. Emergency repair.
Yeah, it was a Code Nine. Can't ignore a Code Nine.
I'm sorry, could we start again? You, you say you had a call-out?
Check the machine.
[OC]: I mean, who'd want to live in a perfect world?
[OC]: I would. I think it'd make a nice change.
Came through on the old sub-ether. Fissure opened up, one patch-up job urgently required.
Yeah. Textbook case. Bit of tweaking round the focal nexus, and Bob's your uncle.
Let me get this straight. Do you mean to say that you're... plumbers?
Yeah. Existential maintenance, that sort of thing.
You mean you repair reality?
No job...
+ PHIL: Too large.
That's our motto.
But you don't think, when I said that, I meant it?
Come again, darling?
I was just talking, you know. I don't really want to live in a perfect world.
You don't want to live in a perfect world? Pull the other one. Who wouldn't want to do that?

Because life isn't perfect. Take away the opportunity to get things wrong and you take away the reason for getting things right. Being human is all about the mistakes, the imperfections, the failures. Burning the toast, losing your keys, getting off at the wrong stop. For some people small pointless blunders are what life is all about.
So... this wasn't a call-out?
No!
I knew it. I told you, Phil. You...
What? It's not my fault. Who are you calling a...?
It's not important whose fault it was. What matters is whether you can put everything back to how it was.
Reversal. It’s not easy. Not easy at all.
What's the matter? Perfection not good enough for ya?

No. I don't want perfection. Because it's real life that matters. I mean, yeah, it'd be nice if things were better, but for that to happen people have to make themselves better. You can't just wave a magic thingy.
Interstitial wave form reticulation spanner.
Exactly. And besides, how boring would a perfect world be? You'd never have anything to moan about, ever.
Quite right. Life doesn't come with satisfaction guaranteed.
Er, well...
It does?
The work comes with a fourteen day no quibble warranty, yeah.
Well, I'm quibbling.
You ain't satisfied?
No!
What about you?
What about me?
It was a joint request. Contractual obligation. So what's it to be? Come on, we haven't got all day. What do you want to happen now?
It's all right, Thomas. There's nothing to be afraid of.
Well, I, er... er... Doctor, what would you do?
It's not my life, Brewster. Only you can decide which path you want to follow.
You're not going with them, the Doctor and Nyssa?
No. 'Cos it's like you said. It's real life that matters. Running around the universe with him, I'd be running away.
Right.

I mean, it's like... I've always been shoved around by other people. Going from place to place. The pudding house, Mister Creek's, Portland Road, the Time Reef. Never found anywhere I wanted to be till now.
Here?
Yeah, well, it's not bad. I mean, might not be perfect, but... has a few things going for it.
What you said back there, in the...
Tardis?
In the Tardis, to those plumbers. You meant it.
I've met two versions of you today. A perfect one and a real one. I want to be with the real one.
Oh, that's sweet.
Because she's funny, she keeps on laughing even when she gets upset and angry with the world, and because the other one was really scary, to be honest.
We'll just have to see how it goes. But we hardly know each other. Things might not work out.
I know. But that's half the fun, isn't it, finding out?
And you realise my life is a total disaster. I'm losing my job, I'm late with my rent, my parents are lunatics.
Can't think of anywhere else I'd rather be.
You wouldn't rather be travelling in Time and Space?
No, I want this. All this. The bridge, the lights, the cars, the smoke, the noise and everything. And you.
They kiss.
Well, come on then, Thomas Brewster. Let's go home and make some mistakes.
Mobile phone rings.
Sorry, I've got to take this. Yes, Mum? I know.
[OC]: Your father’s gone and....
What? You've thrown his clothes on the lawn? And set fire to them. That's wonderful! I mean, evil. We're definitely back in the real world. Yes, Mum. Has anyone phoned the fire brigade?
[OC]: Of course I've phoned the fire brigade. What do you think I am?
Farewell, Thomas Brewster.
I'm surprised he didn't want to stay with us for longer.
I think he travelled enough to know what he wanted when he saw it.
Someone to be with?
Yes. A place to belong. A life. One of those things that... On the other hand, I'm almost insulted. He jumps ship first chance he gets.
Do you think he'll be all right?
Well, he does have a knack for getting himself into trouble, and getting himself out of it again.
But with no money, nowhere to live?
Ah - well, I arranged a little parting gift.
A gift?
The Tardis dematerialises.
The house on Baker Street. No use to me, no good it standing empty. All in his name. The proceeds from the sale should keep him afloat for a while.
But he's from the wrong century. He won't know any of the history or understand the technology. He could have made the biggest mistake of his life.
No. Staying with us would have been the biggest mistake of his life. He made the right decision. And you know, I think he'll probably do very well.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
LUCOR: All crew maintain defence positions, ready to repel boarders.
THOMAS: They're surrounding the ship.
GAMMADES: Dirty, crawling things. What do they want?
NYSSA: They're blind, Commander, and in pain.
DOCTOR: They're drawn to the geometer like moths to a flame. Our dimensions are too heavy. They'd crumple up like umbrellas in a gale.
NYSSA: And they want their friend back.
LUCOR: Easy targets, Commander. We can pick 'em off with the harpoon, one by slithering one.
NYSSA: No!
GAMMADES: Who's giving the orders round here? Proceed, Captain.
DOCTOR: Nyssa's right, Gammades. The blast will destabilise the reef.
NYSSA: The Ruhks are innocent.
LUCOR: Course they are, Miss. About as innocent as your two Doctors.
THOMAS: Look at the Ruhks. What are they doing?
DOCTOR: Something's scared them. Opening up like the Red Sea.
VUYOKI: [OC]: Old Birth! Old Birth, I come to you.
THOMAS: Blimey, it's her. It's Vuyoki.
GAMMADES: Lucor, open the doors.
THOMAS: She's walking straight through them.
LUCOR: Are you crazy?
GAMMADES: Open the doors. It's my Lady. She's coming to us. Oh, she is fearless.
DOCTOR: They're terrified, more like. They can't get out of her way fast enough.
GAMMADES: I must welcome her aboard.
VUYOKI: [OC]: Open up! The Lady Vuyoki demands it.
DOCTOR: Captain Lucor, don't open those doors.
NYSSA: You think it's a trap?
LUCOR: What would she want with the likes of us? We're way below her.
NYSSA: Everybody's below her.
THOMAS: She talked to me.
DOCTOR: Only because she thought you were me. Keep them shut, Lucor.
GAMMADES: [OC]: Lucor, it's Gammades. Get these damn doors open.
DOCTOR: No! Talk to her first. Why’s she here?
GAMMADES: [OC]: Lucor!
LUCOR: Sorry, Doctor. You don't have to live with him. (loud) Disengaging locks, Commander.
GAMMADES: [OC]: About time too.
DOCTOR: Nyssa, Brewster, go down to the hold and try to free the Ruhk.
NYSSA: What about you?
DOCTOR: I have my respects to pay.
